revision.comment: added template {{About-Hugos}} to beginning of section "Awards", and deleted the text already transcluded by the template
revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = ConStellation, the 41st World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Baltimore Convention Center]] | location = [[Baltimore, Maryland]] | country = United States | first = September 1–5, 1983 | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 7,000 | website = }} The '''41st World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]), also known as '''ConStellation''', was held September 1–5, 1983, at the [[Baltimore Convention Center]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], United States. The chairman was [[Michael Walsh (publisher)|Michael J. Walsh]]. Total attendance was approximately 7,000. ==Programming== The guests of honor were [[John Brunner (novelist)|John Brunner]] (pro) and [[David A. Kyle]] (fan). The toastmaster was [[Jack L. Chalker]]. As part of the promotion for the film ''[[The Right Stuff (film)|The Right Stuff]]'', test pilot [[Chuck Yeager]], astronaut [[Gordon Cooper]], plus actors [[Veronica Cartwright]], [[Scott Glenn]], and [[Dennis Quaid]] appeared at ConStellation. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Foundation's Edge]]'' by [[Isaac Asimov]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[Souls (story)|Souls]]" by [[Joanna Russ]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Fire Watch (story)|Fire Watch]]" by [[Connie Willis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Melancholy Elephants]]" by [[Spider Robinson]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Non-Fiction Book|Best Non-Fiction Book]]: ''[[Isaac Asimov: The Foundations of Science Fiction]]'' by [[James Gunn (author)|James E. Gunn]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[Blade Runner]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Edward L. Ferman]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Michael Whelan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]'', edited by [[Charles N. Brown]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Richard E. Geis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[Alexis Gilliland]] ===Other awards=== * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[Paul O. Williams]] ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |agency=Associated Press |work=The New York Times |title=Isaac Asimov Novel Wins a Hugo Award |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/books/isaac-asimov-novel-wins-a-hugo-award.html |date=September 6, 1983 |accessdate=March 29, 2010}} }} == External links == * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1983 NESFA.org: 1983 convention notes] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[40th World Science Fiction Convention]]
Chicon IV in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], United States (1982) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''41st World Science Fiction Convention'''
ConStellation in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]], United States (1983) | after = [[42nd World Science Fiction Convention]]
L.A.con II in [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]], United States (1984) | }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 041}} [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:1983 in Maryland]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:Culture of Baltimore]] [[Category:1983 conferences]]

page.title: Aftermath of the Houthi takeover in Yemen

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)}} The '''aftermath of the Houthi takeover in Yemen''' refers to developments following the [[Houthis]]' takeover of the Yemeni capital of [[Sana'a]] and dissolution of the [[politics of Yemen|government]], which eventually led to a [[Yemeni civil war (2015–present)|civil war]] and the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]].
After seizing the capital in September 2014, the Houthis (Ansar Allah) obtained the resignations of President [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]], Prime Minister [[Khaled Bahah]], and the cabinet in January 2015 and then moved to dissolve [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|parliament]] and instate a [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] to govern Yemen on 6 February 2015.<ref name="shifting">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/26/world/middleeast/yemeni-parliament-cancels-meeting-on-presidents-resignation.html?_r=0|author=Mona El-Naggar|title=Shifting Alliances Play Out Behind Closed Doors in Yemen|year=2015|website=New York Times|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/02/yemen-houthi-rebels-announce-presidential-council-150206122736448.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Houthi rebels announce government takeover|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> However, despite their military successes and an alleged alliance with the former ruling [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/analysis/2014/10/23/Eyeing-return-Yemen-s-ousted-Saleh-helps-Houthis-.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=Eyeing return, Yemen's ousted Saleh aids Houthis|date=23 October 2014|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="hub">{{cite news|agency=Reuters|title=Forces loyal to president seize parts of Yemen's economic hub|date=16 February 2015|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/16/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0LK0R320150216|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> the Houthis faced widespread domestic and international opposition to the coup and they assented to United Nations–led talks on a power-sharing deal.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31359001|publisher=BBC News|title=Yemen talks hit by walkouts over Houthi 'threats'|date=10 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/security-council-hold-emergency-meeting-yemen-28984416|publisher=ABC News|title=UN Security Council OKs Resolution Against Yemen Rebels|first=Cara|last=Anna|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref> At least one analyst went so far as to suggest the Houthis' declaration "fizzled" in the days after it was announced, although they have Iran's material support and [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]]'s political support.<ref name="Charles Schmit 2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.mei.edu/content/at/yemens-ansar-allah-causes-and-effects-its-pursuit-power|author=Charles Schmit|title=Yemen's Ansar Allah: Causes and Effects of Its Pursuit of Power|year=2015|website=American Institute of Yemeni Studies|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref>
On 21 February 2015, one month after Houthi militants confined him to his residence in Sana'a, Hadi slipped out of the capital and traveled to [[Aden]], the old capital of [[South Yemen]]. In a televised address from his hometown, he declared that the Houthi takeover was illegitimate and indicated he remained the constitutional president of Yemen.<ref name="plans">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/21/world/yemen-unrest/index.html|publisher=CNN|title=Yemen's Hadi flees house arrest, plans to withdraw resignation|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="unconst">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-leader-hadi-leaves-sanaa-weeks-house-arrest-150221090018174.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Hadi says Houthis decisions unconstitutional|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="malay">{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2015/02/22/Yemens-ousted-president-Hadi-calls-for-Houthis-to-quit-capital/|work=The Star|title=Yemen's ousted president Hadi calls for Houthis to quit capital|date=22 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> Hadi's ex-ministers were released by the Houthis on 16 March as a "goodwill gesture".<ref name="freepm">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/yemen-houthis-free-prime-minister-house-arrest-150316100312247.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=16 March 2015|accessdate=16 March 2015|title=Yemen's Houthis free prime minister from house arrest}}</ref> On 21 March, Hadi officially proclaimed Aden to be the temporary capital of Yemen, until his pledged recapture of Sana'a.<ref name="capital"/> Within days, however, a [[Southern Yemen offensive (2015)|Houthi-led military campaign]] wrested much of southern Yemen from Hadi's loyalists, prompting Hadi to flee his presidential palace in Aden<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/gregorydjohnsen/is-yemen-about-to-turn-into-a-regional-battleground?bftw=world#.abPmpj8zk|agency=BuzzFeed|title=Is Yemen About To Turn into A Regional Battleground?|first=Gregory|last=Johnson|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> and [[Saudi Arabia]] to [[2015 military intervention in Yemen|launch airstrikes]] against Houthi positions throughout the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-32061632|agency=BBC News|title=Saudi Arabia launches military operation in Yemen - envoy|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref>
==Background== {{Main|2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état}} {{See also|Battle of Sana'a (2014)}} The Houthis took control of much of [[North Yemen|northern Yemen]] by mid-2014. After President Hadi announced an unpopular cut to fuel subsidies, [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]] called for demonstrations. In September 2014, the protests gave way to [[Battle of Sana'a (2014)|full-blown fighting]] between Houthi militants and army forces loyal to General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]] in the capital city of [[Sana'a]]. The Houthis achieved a swift victory, forcing the government to the bargaining table.<ref name="capture">{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/fr/in-depth/features/yemenis-are-shocked-houthi-s-quick-capture-sanaa-690971750|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Yemenis are shocked by Houthis' quick capture of Sana'a|accessdate=7 February 2015|date=September 2014|first=Saeed|last=Al-Batiti}}</ref> In addition to rolling back the fuel subsidy cuts, they also obtained the resignation of Prime Minister [[Mohammed Basindawa]] and significant control over the formation of a new "unity government" and constitution-drafting process.<ref name="agreement">{{cite news|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2014/09/yemen-coup-agreement-political-shift-houthi-saleh-end-wars.html#|agency=Al-Monitor|title=Houthi victory is defeat for Yemen's Islah|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015|first=Adel Moujahed|last=al Shrhabi|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209000230/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2014/09/yemen-coup-agreement-political-shift-houthi-saleh-end-wars.html|archive-date=9 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29530635|publisher=BBC News|title=Yemen's Houthi rebels reject Ahmed Awad bin Mubarak as PM|date=7 October 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
In January 2015, Houthi forces assaulted the presidential palace and private residence of Hadi, placing the president and his ministers under virtual house arrest while demanding further concessions. Hadi and his cabinet resigned on 22 January.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30936940|publisher=BBC|title=Yemen crisis: President resigns as rebels tighten hold|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref> Three weeks later, on 6 February, the Houthis declared the [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|House of Representatives]] defunct and named a Revolutionary Committee led by [[Mohammed Ali al-Houthi]] as the acting authority in Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/Feb-06/286654-yemens-houthi-rebels-announce-they-are-taking-over-the-country-dissolve-parliament.ashx|work=The Daily Star|title=Yemen's Houthis dissolve parliament, take over power|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
==Political developments== [[File:Jamal Benomar at Chatham House.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|[[Jamal Benomar]], the United Nations special envoy to Yemen.]]
===In Sana'a=== ====Cross-factional talks==== UN envoy [[Jamal Benomar]] mediated talks between the Houthis and other major factions in Yemen after the "constitutional declaration". However, the talks were hampered after delegates from the [[Nasserist Unionist People's Organisation]] and [[Al-Islah (Yemen)|Al-Islah]] reportedly walked out, claiming they were threatened by a Houthi representative.<ref name="auto"/> Benomar announced a tentative agreement on 20 February that included the continuation of the [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|House of Representatives]] and the formation of a "people's transitional council" that would represent southerners, women, youth, and other minority groups.<ref name="agreeon">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-feuding-parties-agree-transitional-council-150220065456873.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=20 February 2015|accessdate=19 February 2015|title=Yemen feuding parties agree on transitional council}}</ref>
On 28 February, the [[Southern Movement]] pulled out of negotiations on a political solution to the crisis. Hadi suggested moving the talks to [[Riyadh]], the Saudi Arabian capital, instead of continuing to hold them in Houthi-controlled Sana'a. However, the Houthis and GPC rejected the idea.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1864/news/4938/Houthis-GPC-No-talks-outside-Sana%E2%80%99a.htm|work=Yemen Times|title=HOUTHIS, GPC: NO TALKS OUTSIDE SANA’A|date=2 March 2015|accessdate=3 March 2015|first=Ali Ibrahim|last=Al-Moshki}}</ref> After Hadi refused to participate in the UN talks while the Houthis held Sana'a on 4 March, Houthi fighters seized the headquarters of the [[National Dialogue Conference]], which Hadi had ordered to relocate to Aden.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/reu-yemen-houthis-seize-national-dialogue-headquarters/2668927.html|title=Yemen's Houthis Seize National Dialogue HQ|date=5 March 2015|accessdate=5 March 2015|publisher=Voice of America}}</ref>
====Captive government officials==== On 16 February, former Yemeni President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]]'s [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] (GPC) said it would accept the Houthi decree dissolving parliament. The same day, Benomar and [[Nadia Al-Sakkaf]]reportedly visited Hadi, still under house arrest in Sana'a.<ref name="hub"/> Hadi escaped Sana'a and fled to Aden five days later.<ref name="weeks">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-leader-hadi-leaves-sanaa-weeks-house-arrest-150221090018174.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemeni leader leaves Sanaa after weeks of house arrest|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref>
On 22 February, the Houthis ordered ex-Prime Minister [[Khaled Bahah]] and the cabinet to return to work, but they refused. The group threatened to place them under arrest and criminally charge them if they did not change their minds.<ref name="charge">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/yemens-shiite-rebels-threaten-to-arrest-charge-ministers/2015/02/23/bfaccb48-bb5b-11e4-9dfb-03366e719af8_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=23 February 2015|title=Yemen's Shiite rebels threaten to arrest, charge ministers}}</ref> The Houthis also reportedly tried without success to get the House of Representatives to meet and formally approve Hadi's resignation. The GPC said it would not call for a vote on the resignation, while some smaller parties asserted that without parliamentary action, Hadi remained the "constitutional elected president".<ref name="gccsupport">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/23/world/yemen-unrest/|title=Ousted Yemeni President picks up support from Gulf countries|first=Hakim|last=Almasmari|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The Houthis called Hadi a "fugitive from justice" and said he had "lost his legitimacy to act as president".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/24/us-yemen-security-houthis-idUSKBN0LS1GG20150224|agency=Reuters|title=Houthis say Yemen's Hadi has lost legitimacy, after president flees south|first=Mohammed|last=Ghobari|date=24 February 2015|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref> Both the Houthis and the GPC said they rejected Hadi's claim to be the legitimate president, despite a letter he sent to parliament formally rescinding his resignation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1863/news/4928/President-or-fugitive-Houthis-reject-Hadi%E2%80%99s-letter-to-Parliament.htm|work=Yemen Times|title=PRESIDENT OR FUGITIVE? HOUTHIS REJECT HADI'S LETTER TO PARLIAMENT|first=Ali Ibrahim|last=Al-Moshki|date=25 February 2015|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref> On 10 March, Ali Abdullah Saleh, the chairman of the General People's Congress, harshly criticised Hadi at a news conference in Sana'a. Saleh accused Hadi, his former vice president, of destroying the country and urged him to go into exile.<ref name="exile">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/yemen-leader-asks-president-hadi-exile-150310134751759.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Ex-Yemen leader asks President Hadi to go into exile|date=10 March 2015|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref>
[[Mahmoud al-Subaihi]], Yemen's defence minister, escaped from house arrest in Sana'a and traveled to Aden in early March.<ref name="subaihi">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/03/yemen-defence-minister-escapes-house-arrest-sanaa-150307231427866.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's defence minister escapes house arrest in Sanaa|date=8 March 2015|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> Bahah and his ministers were eventually released in a "goodwill gesture" on 16 March, although Bahah said he would not resume his post as prime minister.<ref name="freepm"/>
===In Aden=== {{see also|Battle of Aden Airport}} [[File:Aden, Yemen Port.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Aden]] became the southern refuge and temporary capital city for [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] and his government in the aftermath of the Houthi takeover.]] A number of members of the dissolved parliament met in [[Aden]] on 15 February and declared it to be Yemen's new capital due to the "occupation" of Sana'a. They also called on the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] to intervene with force against the Houthis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-meeting-called-security-scare-150215075459345.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Anti-Houthi Yemenis call on GCC to intervene|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref> The leaders of the [[Aden Governorate|Aden]], [[Lahij Governorate|Lahij]], and [[Al Mahrah Governorate|Mahrah]] governorates declared a joint "administrative, security, and political leadership" opposing the Houthi takeover.<ref name="timesofoman">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofoman.com/News/47326/Article-Yemens-Houthi-militiamen-defy-threats|agency=Times of Oman|title=Yemen's Houthi militiamen defy 'threats'|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215214418/http://www.timesofoman.com/News/47326/Article-Yemens-Houthi-militiamen-defy-threats|archive-date=15 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Fighters under the command of Hadi's brother Nasser claimed to have seized Aden's TV station and several government buildings in the port city by 16 February, although Governor [[Abdel-Aziz bin Habtour]] denied the station had been taken over.<ref name="hub"/>
Hadi, the former president, reportedly traveled to Aden on 21 February.<ref name="weeks"/> It was not immediately clear whether he evaded house arrest or was allowed to leave for the first time in a month,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/21/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0LP08F20150221|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen ex-president released from house arrest|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="fmr">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/22/world/africa/yemens-former-president-flees-capital.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|title=Yemen's Former Leader, Held by Rebels, Leaves Capital|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> with some reports indicating that he escaped—in one telling, he disguised himself as a woman and stowed away on a food truck,<ref name="fmr"/> while in another, he was freed by special forces—and others suggesting he was released as part of an agreement between the Houthis and other factions.<ref name="newgovt">{{cite news|url=http://www.aawsat.net/2015/02/article55341755/hadi-to-form-new-government-declare-aden-as-capital-of-yemen-sources|agency=Asharq al-Awsat|title=Hadi to form new government, declare Aden as capital of Yemen: sources|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=24 February 2015|first=Arafat|last=Madabish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://extra.globo.com/noticias/mundo/presidente-do-iemen-deixa-capital-do-pais-15402932.html|work=O Globo|language=Portuguese|title=Presidente do Iêmen deixa a capital do país|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> Upon arriving in Aden, Hadi gave a televised address condemning the coup and saying all Houthi actions since 21 September 2014 were invalid and unconstitutional.<ref name="plans"/><ref name="unconst"/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Almasdar Online|url=http://almasdaronline.com/article/68372|title=عاجل|language=Arabic|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> He delivered the address under the title of [[President of Yemen|president]].<ref name="malay"/> In his speech, Hadi called for a resumption of the [[National Dialogue Conference]] in either Aden or [[Taiz]], cities outside the Houthis' [[Houthis#Administration|zone of control]].<ref name="unconst"/><ref name="malay"/> The following day, he met with several southern governors. Bin Habtour said after the meeting that Hadi's intention was to "lead from Aden" and receive foreign delegations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-2963901/Yemen-leader-meets-governors-fleeing-capital.html|work=Daily Mail|title=Yemen leader meets governors after fleeing capital|date=22 February 2015|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> An aide to Hadi said in early March that Hadi considered Aden to have become the country's capital after the Houthis occupied Sana'a.<ref name="subaihi"/> Hadi was soon joined by Defence Minister [[Mahmoud al-Subaihi]], who abandoned his position as chairman of the Houthi-imposed Supreme Security Committee and decamped from Sana'a.<ref name="subaihi"/>
Although he established himself in Aden, Hadi was suspicious of [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] loyalists and Houthi sympathisers even within his hometown. He issued a decree on 2 March reassigning General [[Abdul-Hafez al-Saqqaf]] from the Special Security Forces in Aden to a bureaucratic position. However, al-Saqqaf refused to comply with the decree, amid reports that he did not view Hadi as Yemen's legitimate president.<ref name="tensions">{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1867/news/4960/Tensions-remain-high-in-Aden-over-SSF-position.htm|agency=The Yemen Times|title=TENSIONS REMAIN HIGH IN ADEN OVER SSF POSITION|date=11 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015|first=Ali Ibrahim|last=Al-Moshki}}</ref>
After an [[Battle of Aden Airport|attack]] on [[Aden International Airport]] by al-Saqqaf's commandos, as well as a missile strike by a Houthi jet on his presidential palace, on 19 March, Hadi gave a televised address urging all factions to participate in mediated talks on the country's future in [[Riyadh]] and predicting that the Houthis' "Iranian agenda" would fail.<ref name="cnn"/> On 21 March, he also officially declared Aden to be Yemen's "economic and temporary capital" due to the Houthi occupation of Sana'a, which he pledged would be retaken.<ref name="capital">{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/yemens-president-hadi-declares-new-temporary-capital/a-18332197|publisher=Deutsche Welle|title=Yemen's President Hadi declares new 'temporary capital'|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> Just days later, however, Hadi fled Aden as Houthi forces [[Southern Yemen offensive (2015)#25 March|advanced on the city]] on 25 March. He arrived in [[Saudi Arabia]] the next day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32078817|agency=BBC News|title=President Hadi leaves Yemen as Saudi-led raids continue|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
==Related unrest== ===Clashes=== {{see also|Battle of Aden Airport|Battle of Mukalla (2015)}} There were clashes in [[Rada'a District|Rada'a]] leaving nine dead on 10 February after Houthi fighters attempted to take control of the city and encountered local resistance.<ref name="anniversary">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/02/yemen-marks-uprising-anniversary-anti-houthi-rally-150211060052752.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen marks uprising anniversary with anti-Houthi rally|date=11 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> Twenty-six were killed in clashes between Houthis and [[al Qaeda]]-aligned Sunni tribesmen in the southern [[Al Bayda' Governorate]] on 14 February.<ref name="clashesbetween">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/14/us-emirates-yemen-idUSKBN0LI06H20150214|agency=Reuters|title=Clashes between Shi'ite Houthis and Sunnis in Yemen leave 26 dead|date=14 February 2015|accessdate=14 February 2015|first=Mohammed|last=Ghobari}}</ref> The [[jihad]]ist group [[Ansar al-Sharia (Yemen)|Ansar al-Sharia]] also took advantage of the power vacuum, capturing a military base in the [[Shabwah Governorate]] of southern Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aawsat.net/2015/02/article55341444/yemens-separatists-blame-army-al-qaeda-gains-south|agency=Asharq al-Awsat|title=Yemen's separatists blame army for Al-Qaeda gains in south|date=13 February 2015|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
The Houthis clashed again with tribesmen in [[Al Bayda', Yemen|Al Bayda']] after demonstrations in support of Hadi in several cities on 27 February.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-houthis-deadly-clashes-baida-tribesmen-150228072654506.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Houthis in deadly clashes with Baida tribesmen|date=28 February 2015|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> Three separate al-Qaeda attacks in Al Bayda' Governorate left at least 27 Houthis dead and more injured on 3 March.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-03/04/c_134034804.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|title=27 Houthis killed by al-Qaida attacks in Yemen|date=4 March 2015|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
On 9 March, [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) seized control of [[Al Mahfad District|Al Mahfad]] in southern Yemen's [[Abyan Governorate]] for several hours. A counterattack by the army later that day forced them out of the town. Four soldiers and seven al Qaeda militants were reportedly killed in the fighting.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/yemeni-army-pushes-al-qaida-militants-southern-town-29494367|agency=Yemen's Army Pushes Al-Qaida Militants out of Southern City|date=9 March 2015|accessdate=11 March 2015|first=Ahmed|last=Al-Haj|publisher=ABC News|title=Yemen's Army Pushes Al-Qaida Militants Out of Southern City}}</ref> AQAP seized the [[Al Hawtah District]] on 20 March, again just for a single day, but 29 soldiers were left dead in a mass killing while the city was under jihadist control. A branch of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] later claimed responsibility for the massacre.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=CBS News|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/isis-yemen-carnage-houthi-rebels-advance-in-aqap-territory-toward-hadi/|title=ISIS claims increasing stake in Yemen carnage|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
Amid tension between the Houthis and several military commanders, Houthi fighters attacked the residence of General Mohammed Rajah Laboudha in Sana'a on 17 March, reportedly killing one guard and detaining two others.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/03/18/Gulf-states-say-will-not-allow-Yemen-to-be-place-for-terror-groups.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=Gulf states say will not let Yemen become terrorism hub|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref>
[[Battle of Aden Airport|Major fighting in Aden]] broke out on 19 March, leaving more than a dozen dead, after pro-Saleh troops stormed [[Aden International Airport]]. Hadi loyalists counterattacked, retaking the airport and capturing the base of a rebel general in the city.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/clashes-southern-yemen-force-closure-airport-150319063004697.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen president evacuated as airstrikes target palace|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
===Terrorism=== {{see also|2015 Sana'a mosque bombings}} [[Abdel-Karim al-Kheiwan]], a Houthi leader, was shot dead in Sana'a on 18 March 2015. [[Al Qaeda]] said it carried out the assassination. Two days later, the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] claimed responsibility for four [[suicide attack]]s against [[Shia]] mosques with primarily [[Houthis|Houthi]] congregations in Sana'a. At least 142 people were killed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/two-mosques-yemen-attacked-suicide-bombers-during-friday-prayers-many-injured-671470|agency=Albawaba News|title=BREAKING: Death toll hits 137 from suicide bomb attacks in Yemen mosques|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref>
===Protests=== After the Rada'a clashes on 10 February, the following day, anti-Houthi activists held major protests in [[Ta'izz]] and other cities.<ref name="anniversary"/> Houthi fighters fired on protesters in Ibb on 14 February, leaving four injured,<ref name="clashesbetween"/> and again on 21 February, killing an activist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/world/155548/yemenis-mourn-death-of-protester-by-houthis-in-ibb|agency=World Bulletin|title=Yemenis mourn death of protester by Houthis in Ibb|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
After Hadi's flight from Sana'a to [[Aden]], thousands protested in support of the deposed president in the capital city on 22 February.<ref name="charge"/> A similar demonstration occurred in [[Ta'izz]].<ref name="gccsupport"/> [[Southern Movement|Secessionists]] also rallied in Aden to oppose Hadi's call for unity and national dialogue, chanting that Hadi was "contemptible" for not backing southern independence.<ref>{{cite news|work=Los Angeles Times|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-yemen-aden-20150223-story.html|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=23 February 2015|title=Yemen port city of Aden seethes with separatist fervor}}</ref>
[[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]] called for "protests and demonstrations" against what he alleged was foreign interference on the part of [[Saudi Arabia]] and the United States on 26 February.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aawsat.net/2015/02/article55341882/yemen-houthis-hit-back-over-aden-embassy-move|agency=Asharq al-Awsat|title=Yemen: Houthis hit back over Aden embassy move|date=27 February 2015|accessdate=28 February 2015|first=Hamdan|last=Al-Rahbi}}</ref> On 10 March, thousands reportedly protested in [[Sana'a]] calling for [[Ahmed Saleh]], son of former president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], to be nominated to the presidency.<ref name="exile"/> A similar demonstration was held on 13 March, after pro-Saleh vehicles with loudspeakers reportedly broadcast messages throughout Sana'a urging residents to come out in support of Ahmed Saleh for the preceding two days.<ref name="uae">{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/hundreds-rally-yemen-ex-leaders-son-president-1391372679|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Hundreds rally in Yemen for ex-leader's son as president|date=13 March 2015|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>
==International response== ===Opposition=== [[File:MSC 2014 AlZayani Mueller MSC2014.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|[[Abdulatif al-Zayani]], secretary-general of the [[Gulf Co-operation Council|GCC]], staunchly opposed the Houthi takeover, backing [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi|Hadi]]'s claim to legitimacy.]] International reactions to the Houthi takeover were generally negative, with the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]], [[Arab League]], [[European Union]], United States, and United Nations all criticising the coup.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/07/GCC-warns-Houthi-coup-in-Yemen-poses-regional-risk-.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=GCC warns Houthi 'coup' in Yemen poses regional risk|date=7 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sabanews.net/en/news387615.htm|agency=Yemen News Agency (SABA)|title=EU welcomes Yemeni political parties' return to dialogue|date=10 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.alalam.ir/news/1674662|agency=Al-Alam|date=8 February 2015|title=Ban Ki-moon Odd Suggestion for Yemen|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/16867-arab-league-denounces-houthi-coup-in-yemen|agency=Middle East Monitor|title=Arab League denounces Houthi coup in Yemen|date=9 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> The United States and United Kingdom moved swiftly to close their embassies and evacuate their ambassadors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/10/U-S-embassy-in-Yemen-closing-completely-staff-.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=U.S. embassy in Yemen closing completely: staff|date=10 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/02/closes-yemen-embassy-orders-ambassador-leave-150210162223469.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=US closes Yemen embassy and orders ambassador to leave|date=10 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/11/british-embassy-in-yemen-evacuated-and-closed-amid-growing-crisis|work=The Guardian|title=British embassy in Yemen evacuated and closed amid growing crisis|date=11 February 2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Turkey, and the United Arab Emirates followed suit.<ref name="hub"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31457402|publisher=BBC News|title=Yemen unrest: Saudi Arabia closes embassy|date=13 February 2015|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=Sputnik International|url=http://sputniknews.com/europe/20150213/1018212551.html|title=Netherlands Shutters Embassy in Yemen As Tensions Mount|date=13 February 2015|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/middle-east/61108-150214-uae-spain-shut-embassies-in-yemen-capital|agency=i24 News|title=UAE, Spain shut embassies in Yemen capital|date=14 February 2015|accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/15/U-N-to-urge-Houthis-to-step-aside-in-Yemen-.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=Houthis refuse to cede power in Yemen|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-1-302219-Japan-closes-Yemen-embassy|work=The News International|date=17 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015|title=Japan closes Yemen embassy}}</ref>
The [[United Nations Security Council]] unanimously adopted a resolution deploring the Houthi takeover and demanding that the group relinquish control of the government on 15 February 2015, although it stopped short of authorising military force.<ref name="auto1"/> The GCC warned that if the UN did not act forcefully, its members would "take measures which enable them to maintain their vital interests in the security and stability of Yemen".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/2015/02/15/3491458/yemens-neighbors-warn-of-action.html|work=The Tribune|title=Yemen's neighbors warn of action if world fails to intervene|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref>
A Saudi delegation met with Hadi on 23 February, days after his escape to [[Aden]]. Aides to Hadi said the delegation informed him that [[government of Saudi Arabia|Riyadh]] continued to recognise him as president. The GCC also called on the Yemeni people to support Hadi against the Houthis.<ref name="gccsupport"/> Hadi also met with a GCC delegation, including Secretary-General [[Abdulatif al-Zayani]]. On 26 February, the Saudi ambassador to Yemen relocated his mission from [[Sana'a]] to Aden.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/26/us-yemen-security-saudi-idUSKBN0LU1SR20150226|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen government: Saudi ambassador decamps to Aden from Houthi-controlled capital|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref> [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]] responded by accusing Saudi Arabia of destabilising the country and financing those who "aim to hurt the people of Yemen".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/houthi-leader-accuses-saudi-arabia-of-destabilizing-yemen-1424981699|work=The Wall Street Journal|title=Houthi Leader Accuses Saudi Arabia of Destabilizing Yemen|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref> [[Bahrain]], the [[United Arab Emirates]], and [[Kuwait]] also announced they would relocate their embassies to Aden.<ref name="flights">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/yemen-iran-sign-agreement-open-direct-flight-routes-29296222|title=Yemen, Iran Sign Agreement to Open Direct Flight Routes|date=28 February 2015|accessdate=28 February 2015|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> On 10 March, al-Houthi claimed the Gulf states were working "to facilitate the atmosphere for al Qaeda in the southern provinces".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/10/us-yemen-crisis-idUSKBN0M62AV20150310|agency=Reuters|title=Houthi leader accuses Gulf states of backing al Qaeda in Yemen|date=10 March 2015|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref>
The United States reportedly withdrew the last of its special forces from Yemen in March 2015.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/21/middleeast/yemen-unrest/|publisher=CNN|title=Sources: U.S. pulling last of its Special Operations forces out of Yemen|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> The United Kingdom followed suit, with its remaining troops being airlifted out of Sana'a.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1450747/british-special-forces-pull-out-of-yemen|publisher=Sky News|title=British Special Forces Pull Out of Yemen|first=Alistair|last=Bunkell|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
===Support=== The [[government of Iran|government]] of [[Iran]] praised the Houthi uprising as an extension of the [[Iranian Revolution]], with President [[Hassan Rouhani]] stating that the Islamic Republic was supporting "peace and stability" in Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/02/iran-yemen-houthis-axis-of-resistance.html#|agency=Al-Monitor|title=Does Iran really control Yemen?|date=12 February 2015|accessdate=28 February 2015|first=Shahir|last=ShahidSaless}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/iran-supporting-stability-yemen-rouhani-2123987899|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Iran supporting 'stability' in Yemen: Rouhani|date=12 February 2015|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> On 28 February, Houthi-controlled state media announced that Iran and Yemen signed an agreement to open direct flight routes between the two countries.<ref name="flights"/> The following month, a Houthi spokesperson said the group had secured pledges from Iran to provide oil to Yemen, expand its ports, and construct power plants in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/houthis-secured-aid-package-iran-150314123957118.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Houthis say they have secured aid package from Iran|date=14 March 2015|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>
===Foreign involvement=== {{see also|2015 military intervention in Yemen}}
====Saudi Arabia==== After [[Riad Yassin]], Hadi's foreign minister, called on the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] to assist the beleaguered government in [[Aden]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32022450|publisher=BBC News|title=Yemen minister calls for Gulf military intervention|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> [[Saudi Arabia]] began a [[Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia|military]] buildup on its border with Yemen in late March 2015, according to US intelligence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/24/saudi-arabia-military-yemen_n_6935702.html|work=The Huffington Post|title=Saudi Arabia Military Amasses Near Yemen Border: U.S. Officials|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> On 25 March, Saudi Arabia began launching airstrikes in Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/report-yemens-embattled-president-flees-stronghold-as-rebels-advance/2015/03/25/e0913ae2-d2d5-11e4-a62f-ee745911a4ff_story.html|work=The Washington Post|title=Saudi Arabia launches air attacks in Yemen|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> Yemeni Houthi rebels asks UN to stop Saudi Arabian strikes against them follow continued blatant aggression on Yemen by Saudi.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/02/us-yemen-saudi-war-idUSKBN0NN0OY20150502</ref>
====United States==== According to [[Michael G. Vickers]], U.S. Undersecretary of Defense for Intelligence, the United States established an intelligence relationship with the Houthis to counter [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]].<ref>{{cite news|author1=Joseph Braude|title=A Growing Rift Between Washington and the Gulf States on Yemen|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joseph-braude/a-growing-rift-between-wa_b_6778594.html?ir=Politics|accessdate=2 March 2015|work=The Huffington Post|date=1 March 2015}}</ref> The U.S. ambassador to Yemen, [[Matthew H. Tueller]], met with Hadi after his escape to Aden and said the U.S. still viewed him as the "legitimate" president despite the Houthi takeover. However, the U.S. said it had no plans to relocate its shuttered embassy from Sana'a.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mei.edu/content/news/us-says-no-plans-move-embassy-yemen-aden|publisher=Middle East Institute|date=3 March 2015|accessdate=3 March 2015|title=US says no plans to move embassy in Yemen to Aden}}</ref>
==Civil war== {{Main|Yemeni civil war (2015–present)}} {{See also|Battle of Aden (2015)}} After the [[Battle of Aden Airport]] and [[2015 Sana'a mosque bombings|Sana'a mosque bombings]], the Houthi [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] declared on 21 March a "state of general mobilisation", in light of the actions of the pro-Hadi Popular Committees and "terrorist elements".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sabanews.net/ar/news391987.htm|language=Arabic|title=اللجنة الثورية تعلن التعبئة العامة وتوجه الأمن والجيش القيام بواجبه للتصدي للإرهابيين|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015|agency=Saba News Agency}}</ref>
On 22 March, the Houthis seized [[Taiz]] without resistance, although Houthi gunmen reportedly fired into the air to disperse protests against their takeover.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/22/houthi-yemen-fighting_n_6918306.html|work=The Huffington Post|title=Houthis Seize Strategic City in Yemen, Escalating Power Struggle|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> The group took control of the military airbase in the city and reportedly flew troops and materiel into the airfield. The Houthi advance was assisted by forces loyal to Saleh.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/23/world/middleeast/houthi-rebels-taiz-yemen.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|title=Rebels Seize Key Parts of Yemen's Third-Largest City, Taiz|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> The next day, Houthi forces were dispatched to [[Mocha, Yemen|Mocha]], a major port on the [[Bab-el-Mandeb]] strait.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/world/yemens-houthi-rebels-move-on-strategic-gulf-waterway|work=The National|title=Yemen's Houthi rebels move on strategic Gulf waterway|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref>
The Houthi offensive advanced dramatically on 25 March, with the systematic falls of [[Al Anad Air Base]], [[Lahij]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/25/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0ML0YC20150325|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen's Houthi militia close in on president's Aden base|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf}}</ref> and [[Aden International Airport]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/25/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0ML0YC20150325|agency=Reuters|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|title=Allies of Yemen Houthis seize Aden airport, close in on president|first=Sami|last=Aboudi}}</ref> and the reported capture of Defence Minister [[Mahmoud al-Subaihi]] by Houthi fighters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aa.com.tr/en/politics/483542--yemens-houthis-detain-defense-minister-in-lahij|agency=Anadolu Agency|title=Yemen's Houthis detain defense minister in Lahij|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> Amid disputed reports that Hadi fled the country,<ref name="ao-deal">{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/126085.aspx|agency=Ahram Online|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|title=Yemen's President Hadi still in Aden but isolated: Sources|first=Ahmed|last=Eleiba}}</ref> Yemeni Foreign Minister [[Riad Yassin]] called on [[Arab world|Arab states]] to intervene in the country's crisis.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/03/25/rebels-yemen-air-base/70417062/|title=Yemen's foreign minister calls for Arab intervention|first=Jane|last=Onyanga-Omara|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|work=USA Today}}</ref>
[[Shuqrah]] on the [[Arabian Sea]], east of Aden, fell to the Houthis on 27 March, giving the militants control of all land entrances to Aden. [[Battle of Aden (2015)|Fighting]] was reported on the outskirts of the provisional capital itself.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/Mar-27/292400-yemen-houthi-forces-gain-first-foothold-on-arabian-sea-residents.ashx|agency=The Daily Star|title=Yemen Houthi forces gain first foothold on Arabian Sea: residents|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> By the start of April, Houthi and allied military forces had pressed into central Aden, taking control of the presidential palace on 2 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/01/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0MS4Y120150401|title=Yemen Houthi fighters backed by tanks reach central Aden|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf|agency=Reuters|date=1 April 2015|accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32157994|agency=BBC News|title=Yemen crisis: Rebels storm presidential palace in Aden|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref>
===Saudi-led air campaign=== {{Main|2015 military intervention in Yemen}} Later that day, the Gulf states made a joint announcement that they would mount a military intervention against the Houthis, [[al Qaeda]], and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] in Yemen.<ref name="jointstate">{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/03/26/GCC-states-to-repel-Houthi-aggression-in-Yemen-statement-.html|title=Gulf states decide 'to repel Houthi aggression'|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|agency=Al Arabiya}}</ref> [[Saudi Arabia]]'s ambassador to the [[United States]] announced the kingdom launched airstrikes against Houthi targets overnight.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2015/03/154834/gcc-led-coalition-starts-airstrikes-agaisnt-houti-rebels-yemen/|agency=Morocco World News|title=GCC-Led Coalition Starts Airstrikes Agaisnt (sic) Houti Rebels in Yemen|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[Morocco]], and [[Sudan]] also joined the campaign, with Egyptian naval ships moving to block the [[Bab-el-Mandeb]] strait,<ref name="voa">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/saudi-led-airstrikes-continue-for-second-day-in-yemen/2696496.html|agency=Voice of America|title=Egyptian, Saudi Vessels Approach Yemen Coast|first=Edward|last=Yeranian|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCAKBN0ML0YC20150328|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen Houthi rebels advance despite Saudi-led air strikes|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref> and the [[United States]] declared it would provide intelligence and logistical support.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/27/saudi-arabia-gets-bipartisan-backing-for-yemen-airstrikes |agency=U.S. News and World Report |title=Saudi Arabia Gets Bipartisan Backing for Yemen Airstrikes |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=27 March 2015 |first=Julian |last=Pecquet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328004338/http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/27/saudi-arabia-gets-bipartisan-backing-for-yemen-airstrikes |archivedate=28 March 2015 }}</ref>
Hadi arrived in Riyadh on 26 March, reportedly by way of [[Oman]]. He was greeted by the Saudi defence minister, [[Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/26/hadi-saudi-riyadh_n_6948558.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Saudi Arabia: Yemen's President Hadi Arrives In Saudi Capital Riyadh|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150216231342/http://midwestdiplomacy.com/2015/01/26/demystifying-yemens-conflict/ Demystifying Yemen's Conflict (Midwest Diplomacy)] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/country_profiles/1706450.stm Timeline: Yemen (BBC)]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Cleanup|date=August 2009}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Some Editions of the Bannawag Magazine.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Some copies of ''Bannawag'' issues]] -->
'''''Bannawag''''' ([[Iloko]] word meaning "dawn") is a Philippine weekly magazine published in the [[Philippines]] by Liwayway Publications Inc. It contains serialized novels/comics, [[short stories]], poetry, essays, news features, entertainment news and articles, among others, that are written in Ilokano, a language common in the northern regions of the Philippines.
''Bannawag'' has been acknowledged as one foundation of the existence of contemporary Iloko literature. It is through the ''Bannawag'' that every [[Ilokano writers|Ilokano writer]] has proved his mettle by publishing his first Iloko short story, poetry, or essay, and thereafter his succeeding works, in its pages. The magazine is also instrumental in the establishment of [[GUMIL Filipinas]], the umbrella organization of Ilokano writers in the Philippines and in other countries.
==History== Bannawag magazine was conceived in 1934 when [[Magdaleno A. Abaya]] of Candon, Ilocos Sur, who was then a member of the editorial staff of the Graphic magazine, an English weekly published by the Roces Publications, presented the concept of an Ilokano publication to the management of the Graphic magazine. [[Don Ramos Roces]], the owner-publisher of Graphic magazine and other vernacular magazines which included [[Liwayway]], [[Bisaya]] and [[Hiligaynon language|Hiligaynon]], scoffed at the idea when Abaya presented the proposal to put a magazine for Ilocanos.
But Abaya did not lose hope until Don Ramos gave his consent-with condition that the first issues were only for a try-out, that after one or two months without improvement in the sales, it will be stopped. Abaya was elated and hurried to find willing companions to help him run the magazine. In the end, he was able to persuade Mauro Peña to be the magazine's assistant and news editor, [[Francisco Fuentecilla]] of Zambales as assistant and news editor,; and Benjamin Gray, also of [[Candon]], [[Ilocos Sur]], as proofreader. Thus, Bannawag or "Dawn," or the Iloko equivalent of Liwayway, was born.
Bannawag's first issue on November 3, 1934 had a production run of 10,000 copies with a selling price of PHP 0.10 per copy. The magazine was an instant success beyond the belief of Don Ramon, and he allowed the continued publication of the magazine.
During the Second World War, the combined U.S. and Philippine Commonwealth ground troops to fought by the Japanese Imperial forces led by General Tomoyuki Yamashita around the fall the battles started the liberation in Northern Luzon in 1945.
When Roces Publications was sold to [[Hans M. Menzi]] in 1966, the name was changed to Liwayway Publishing, Inc. Thirty nine years later, in 2005, the publication of Bannawag was transferred to [[Manila Bulletin]] Publishing Corporation. [[Clesencio B. Rambaud]], [[Prudencio Gar. Padios]] and [[Juan Al. Asuncion]] were tasked to man Bannawag. However, Padios migrated to [[Canada]] in October 2006 and [[Ariel S. Tabag]] of [[Sta. Teresita, Cagayan]] was recruited to fill in the vacancy,
==New Bannawag== ''Bannawag'' underwent significant metamorphosis when its publication when taken over by the Manila Bulletin, from its content, color, quality of paper used, page layout, and other aspects to keep up with the needs of the times. These changes made the magazine more prestigious in its tasks in bringing entertainment, information, and inspiration to millions of readers in the language spoken by hardly Ilocanos and in depicting the different aspects of the Ilocano character.
Recently, it was picked up by the department of education as one of the important references of the educational system in Ilocano-speaking areas in the country.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
==Present== ''Bannawag'' has gone a long way from its 10-centavo cost for each edition in the 1930s and is moving vigorously to live up the past as an important part of today and tomorrow's dream of the Ilocanos.
==Diamond jubilee== <!-- note: Bannawag is not yet online (provide URL of its site if it's now online, please... and the diamond anniversary is yet to happen. It goes online on February 2, 2008 to face a wider audience. It has celebrated its Diamond Anniversary on November 3, 2009. --> ''Bannawag'' celebrated its [[diamond jubilee]] on November 3, 2009. In celebration of this, ''Bannawag'' launched the planting of Bannawag Diamond Jubilee trees in municipal parks and lots, school sites, and other public spaces. Jim Domingo, a retired professor and university official of [[Cagayan State University]], was instrumental in the planting.
==See also== *''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' *''[[Liwayway]]'' *[[Greg Laconsay]] *''[[Hiligaynon magazine]]'' *''[[Bisaya Magasin]]''
[[Category:Magazines established in 1934]] [[Category:Philippine literary magazines]] [[Category:Entertainment magazines]] [[Category:Philippine-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Philippine comics magazines]] [[Category:Manila Bulletin]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{for|the song Bui Doi|Miss Saigon}} The Vietnamese term '''bụi đời''' ("dust of life") refers to [[vagrancy (people)|vagrants]] in the city, or, '''''trẻ bụi đời''''' to [[street children]] or juvenile gangs. From 1989, following a song in the musical ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', '''"Bui-Doi"'''<ref>Theater Yearbook 1990-1991: The Complete Broadway and Off-Broadway ... - Page 26 Otis L. Guernsey, Jeffrey Sweet - 2000 "Nowhere is the dichotomy of good intentions and cheesy realization more blatant then in the song "Bui-Doi," an appeal on behalf of the outcast, half-breed illegitimate offspring Americans left behind in Southeast Asia."</ref> came to popularly refer to [[Amerasian]] children left behind in Vietnam after the [[Vietnam War]].
==Rural poor coming to the towns== [[File:Dust of Life (1957 film poster).jpg|thumb|right|222px|1957 film poster ''Dust of Life''.]] The term ''bụi đời'' ("dust of life") originally referred to the starving people of the countryside taking refuge in towns, in the 1930s.<ref>Philippe M. F. Peycam - ''The Birth of Vietnamese Political Journalism: Saigon, 1916-1930'' Page 24 2012 "Often referred to as bụi đời [dust of life], they were described by the communist newspaper of the 1930s, La Lutte, as the "starving people from the countryside taking refuge in towns." 42 Owing to the lack of heavy industry, ...</ref> The term ''trẻ bụi đời'' "young vagrants," now refers to street children or juvenile gang members. It is intended to bring to mind an image of a child abandoned and moving about without purpose, like dust. In Vietnamese, it has no racial connotation. Vietnamese refer to Amerasians as ''Mỹ lai'' (mixed American and Vietnamese), ''con lai'' (mixed-race child), or ''người lai'' (mixed-race person).
The connection to mixed-race parentage given in Western media, from connection with ''Miss Saigon'', is not widely known in Vietnam today. The term ''bụi đời'' in Vietnam today refers to any people, but usually young men, who live on the street or live as wanderers. A related verb ''đi bụi'' ("go dust") means someone who has left their home, usually due to arguments with their family, to take on the ''bụi đời'' wandering or street life.
==Miss Saigon and Amerasian orphans== In the West, the term '''Bui-Doi''' became widely known from the use in the dialogue, and particularly the song title "Bui-Doi", of the 1989 musical ''Miss Saigon'' by [[Claude-Michel Schönberg]] and [[Alain Boublil]], which opened in 1991 on [[Broadway theater|Broadway]], and, until its closing in 2001, was the eleventh longest running Broadway musical in musical theater history. The song "Bui-Doi" had lyrics written by Alain Boublil and Richard Maltby, Jr. They took the term ''bụi đời'' to mean not Vietnamese [[street children]], but the [[Amerasian]] offspring of American soldiers and Vietnamese mothers abandoned at the end of the [[Vietnam War]].<ref>Matthew Bernstein, Gaylyn Studlar Visions of the East: Orientalism in Film - Page 167 1997 "Here, the character John (an army friend of the male lead) stands facing the audience in front of a lectern on a dimly lit and bare stage. As he sings the number "Bui Doi" (dust of life), a collage of children's images is projected onto ...."</ref><ref>The Theater Mania guide to musical theater recordings - Page 244 Michael Portantiere, TheaterMania.com (Firm) - 2004 "The French-speaking librettist Boublil's collaboration with Richard Maltby, Jr. yielded lyrics that are awkwardly ... Although it's difficult to pick the nadir of the score, a good candidate is "Bui Doi," a shamelessly manipulative plea on behalf of ..."</ref><ref>R. Andrew Lambert ''Beginning a Prayer Life'' Page 18 - 2009 "In Vietnam, children like me (Amerasians) were called Bụi Đời "dust of life" and we were hated and ostracized by Vietnamese society. I was left with another Vietnamese family for which my mother was to regularly pay what she could."</ref>
==Mixed race children in Vietnam== {{main|Amerasian}} The majority of mixed race people after the Vietnam war were Amerasians or children of Vietnamese mothers and military or civilian men from the United States. Amerasians born during the [[Vietnam War]] (1964–75) could be the issue of anything from long-term unions to rape. Due to the large sex industry brought on by the military economy, Amerasians were predominantly seen as off-spring of GI fathers and [[Prostitution in Vietnam|prostitute mothers]]. Life was frequently difficult for such Amerasians; they existed as pariahs in [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] society. Often, they would be persecuted by the communist government and sometimes even sold into prostitution as children.<ref name=FrontPage>{{cite web|last=Benge|first=Michael|title=The Living Hell of Amerasians|url=http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=6535|publisher=[[FrontPage Magazine]]|accessdate=8 January 2011|date=22 November 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301204219/http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=6535#|archive-date=2014-03-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Under the [[Amerasian Homecoming Act]] of 1988, a Vietnamese Amerasian could obtain a U.S. visa on the basis of appearance alone. Amerasians gained the attention of con artists who claimed to be their relatives in the hope of obtaining visas.<ref name="Trin">''Surviving twice: Amerasian children of the Vietnam War'' By Trin Yarborough, p. 103.</ref> About 23,000 Amerasians immigrated to the U.S. under this act.
In the United States, ''bui doi'', or the term "dust of life", again referred to the criminal class, where the youths included newly transplanted Vietnamese and Amerasians.<ref>''The bubbling cauldron: race, ethnicity, and the urban crisis'' By Michael P. Smith, Joe R. Feagin, p. 68.</ref> The misuse of the word ''bui doi'' also migrated to the United States and was appropriated by the mainstream.
==In popular culture==
The 1977 made-for-TV movie "Green Eyes" was a fictional movie about an American veteran who makes a trip back to Southeast Asia to search for his son from a liaison with a Vietnamese woman. He encounters a boy with green eyes who insists that he must be half American and thus eligible to go to America.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
The 1994 documentary film ''Bui doi: Life Like Dust'' uses the term to describe Ricky Phan, a Vietnamese refugee who turned to a life of crime after escaping from Vietnam to California.<ref>http://www.idfa.nl/industry/tags/project.aspx?id=31e3f335-4486-4672-b646-91ddae0d7f59</ref>
The 2004 movie ''[[The Beautiful Country]]'' depicts the life of a fictional ''bui doi'' and his efforts to become reunited with his American father. The prologue to The Beautiful Country opens with a definition: "Bui Doi: 'less than dust' Term used to describe Vietnamese children with American fathers."<ref>Soil and Culture - Page 92 Edward R. Landa, Christian Feller - 2010 "The prolog to The Beautiful Country (2004) is a definition: "Bui Doi: "less than dust" Term used to describe Vietnamese children with American fathers" The film follows such a Vietnamese young man, Binh, from his escape from Vietnam to ... "</ref>
The 2014 movie ''[[Noble (film)|Noble]]'', a true life story of Christina Noble, who overcomes the harsh difficulties of her childhood in Ireland to find her calling by helping the bụi đời on the streets of Ho Chi Minh City.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
==See also== {{Portal|United States|Vietnam}} * [[Lai Đại Hàn]] * [[Konketsuji]] * [[Luk khrueng]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * The song [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fdi8c70rE_4 "Bui Doi"] from the musical ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' (1989). Sung by [[Peter Polycarpou]]. Lyrics by [[Alain Boublil]]. Music by [[Claude-Michel Schönberg]]. {{Multiethnicity}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bui doi (term)}} [[Category:Multiracial affairs in Asia]] [[Category:Vietnamese diaspora]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Ethnic groups of partial Asian ancestry]] [[Category:Ethnic groups of partial European ancestry]] [[Category:Vietnamese words and phrases]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Cat piano|the award-winning animated short film|The Cat Piano}} {{For|cat organs|Cat anatomy}} [[File:Cat piano 1883.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|from ''La Nature'', 1883]]
[[Image:katzenkavalier 2.jpg|right|250px|thumb|from J-B. Weckerlin, ''Musiciana'' (1877)]] [[File:Badenis Katzenmusik (Gustav Brandt).jpg|thumb|''[[Kladderadatsch]]'' (1897) parodies [[Count Kasimir Felix Badeni|Count Badeni]] in a caricature of him accompanied by ''Katzenjammermusik'' {{bracket|cat whine music}}]] [[File:Die Gartenlaube (1858) b 608.jpg|thumb|Depiction in 1858 ''[[Die Gartenlaube]]'' short, "Katzen-Orgel"]] [[File:Ravel - Boléro félin.PNG|thumb|Caricature drawing of a cat walking at the pace of Bolero, meowing the theme]]
A '''cat organ''' or '''cat piano''' ({{lang-de|Katzenorgel}} or ''Katzenklavier'', {{lang-fr|orgue à chats}} or ''piano à chats/piano chats'') is a hypothetical [[musical instrument]] which consists of a line of [[cat]]s fixed in place with their tails stretched out underneath a [[keyboard instrument|keyboard]] so that they [[cat communication|cry out]] when a key is pressed. The cats would be arranged according to the natural [[pitch (music)|tone]] of their voices.
==Origins==
There is no official record of a cat organ actually being built; rather it is described in literature as a bizarre concept. "The details of the cat organ present it clearly as an instrument cat lovers might wish was a fictional horror."<ref name="Betancourt">Betancourt, Michael (2011). {{Cite web |url=http://vagueterrain.net/content/2011/05/birth-sampling |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-04-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602011022/http://vagueterrain.net/content/2011/05/birth-sampling# |archive-date=2013-06-02 |dead-url=bot: unknown |df= }}</ref> The instrument is used in stories which criticize the cruelty of royalty while the [[piganino]], a similar instrument using pigs, has been used to criticize the poor.
This instrument was described by the French writer [[Jean-Baptiste Weckerlin]] in his book ''Musiciana, extraits d’ouvrages rare ou bizarre'' (Musiciana, descriptions of rare or bizarre inventions):<ref>Weckerlin, Jean-Baptiste (1877). ''Musiciana, extraits d'ouvrages rare ou bizarre'', p.349. Paris: Garnier Freres. Cited in {{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=diEVidYxO7cC&pg=PA195 |title=The Tiger In The House |first=Carl|last=Van Vechten|isbn=9781417967445 |date=2004-10-01 }}</ref>
{{quote|When the King of Spain [[Philip II of Spain|Felipe II]] was in [[Brussels]] in 1549 visiting his father the [[Emperor Charles V]], each saw the other rejoicing at the sight of a completely singular procession. At the head marched an enormous bull whose horns were burning, between which there was also a small devil. Behind the bull a young boy sewn into a bear skin rode on a horse whose ears and tail were cut off. Then came the archangel Saint Michael in bright clothing, and carrying a balance in his hand.
The most curious was on a chariot that carried the most singular music that can be imagined. It held a bear that played the organ; instead of pipes, there were sixteen cat heads each with its body confined; the tails were sticking out and were held to be played as the strings on a piano, if a key was pressed on the keyboard, the corresponding tail would be pulled hard, and it would produce each time a lamentable [[meow]]. The historian [[Juan Christoval Calvete]], noted the cats were arranged properly to produce a succession of notes from the octave... ([[chromatic scale|chromatically]], I think).
This abominable orchestra arranged itself inside a theatre where monkeys, wolves, deer and other animals danced to the sounds of this infernal music.<ref>{{cite book|last=Weckerlin|first=Jean-Baptiste|authorlink=Jean-Baptiste Weckerlin|title=Musiciana, extraits d’ouvrages rare ou bizarre|location=Paris|date=1877|page=349}}</ref>}}
The instrument was described by German physician [[Johann Christian Reil]] (1759–1813) for the purpose of treating patients who had lost the ability to focus their attention. Reil believed that if they were forced to see and listen to this instrument, it would inevitably capture their attention and they would be cured: "A fugue played on this instrument--when the ill person is so placed that he cannot miss the expression on their faces and the play of these animals--must bring Lot's wife herself from her fixed state into conscious awareness."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.uchicago.edu/research/jnl-crit-inq/issues/v24/v24n3.richards.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-05-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606101253/http://www.uchicago.edu/research/jnl-crit-inq/issues/v24/v24n3.richards.html# |archive-date=2011-06-06 |dead-url=bot: unknown |df= }} from Richards, Robert J. "Rhapsodies on a Cat-Piano, or [[Johann Christian Reil]] and the Foundations of Romantic Psychiatry", 1998.</ref>
The instrument was first described by [[Athanasius Kircher]] in his 1650 work ''Musurgia Universalis'', though the lack of an image may have left doubt in the minds of some writers. (''The New York Times'', for example, has carried an article claiming he described the instrument,<ref name=NYT1>{{Citation | last = Boxer| first = Sarah| title = A Postmodernist Of the 1600s Is Back in Fashion| newspaper = The New York Times | publication-place = New York| date = 25 May 2002| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/25/arts/a-postmodernist-of-the-1600-s-is-back-in-fashion.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm }}</ref> and another stating he did not describe it in ''Musurgia Universalis''.<ref name=NYT2>{{Citation | last = Schuessler| first = Jennifer| title = A 17th-Century Genius, a Quack, or Perhaps Both | newspaper = The New York Times | publication-place = New York| date = 30 December 2012| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/31/books/a-man-of-misconceptions-by-john-glassie.html}}</ref>). His description appears in Book 6, Part 4, Chapter 1, under the heading "Corollaria," (emphasis added):
{{quote|Constructum non ita pridem ad melancholiam magni cuiusdam Principis depellendam abinsigni ingeniosoque Histrione tale quodpiam instrumentum. Feles vivas accepit omnes differentis magnitudinis, quas cistae cuidam huic negotio dedita opera fabricatae ita inclusit ut caudae perforamina extentae, certis quibusdam cana, libus insererentur affixae, hisce subdidit palmulas subtilissimis ac uleis loco malleolorum instructas; '''Feles vero iuxta differentem magnitudinem tonatim ita disposuit'''; ut singulae palmulae singulis responderent felium caudis, '''instrumentumque ad relaxationem Principis praeparatum oportuno loco condidit, quod deinde pulsatum eam harmonia''m'' redditit, quale''m'' Feliu''m'' voces reddere possunt'''. Nam palmulae digitis Organoe di depressae aculeis suis du''m'' caudas pu''n''gunt cattoru''m'' hi in rabiem acti miserabili voce, nunc gravem, modò acutam intonantes, eam ex felium vocibus compositam reddiderunt harmoniam, quae ''et'' moveret homines ad risum, ''et'' vel sorices ipsos ad saltum concitare posset.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kircher|first=Athanasius|authorlink=Athanasius Kircher|title=Musurgia universalis|url=http://hz.imslp.info/files/imglnks/usimg/d/db/IMSLP253537-PMLP410795-athanasiikircherkirc_musurgia_1.6.pdf|page=519|date=1650|location=Rome}}</ref>{{efn|Paraphrase: This remarkably clever instrument was built not so long ago to try to dispel the melancholy of the prince. Live cats of all sizes where placed in a box built for this purpose, containing sharp points near the tails so that they struck cats of different sizes, producing different pitches when different keys where pressed. The performance of this frenzy of cat voices in harmony, sometimes in misery, sometimes in anger, caused amusement.}}}}
[[Image:katzenkavalier.jpg|right|250px|thumb|from Gaspar Schott, ''Magia Naturalis'' (1657)]]
The citation is noted by Kircher's student [[Gaspar Schott]] in ''Magia Naturalis naturae et artis,'' Part 2, Book 6, Pragmatia 2, titled "Felium Musicam exhibere [Cat Concert]."<ref>{{cite book|first=Gaspar|last=Schott|authorlink=Gaspar Schott|title=Magia universals naturae et artis|date=1657}}: [http://lhldigital.lindahall.org/cdm/ref/collection/philsci/id/20194 Text] and [http://lhldigital.lindahall.org/cdm/ref/collection/philsci/id/20194 Image] at Linda Hall Library.</ref>
==Modern citations and reconstructions== [[Michael Betancourt]] compares the [[sampling (music)|sampling]] of cats' meows used in [[Jingle Cats]]' albums, ''Meowy Christmas'' (1993) and ''Here Comes Santa Claws'' (1994), to the cat organ,<ref name="Betancourt"/> in that both require cats, but diminish each performer's importance.
Kircher notes that the instrument can be used to reduce the melancholy of princes by moving them to laughter, almost exactly the situation that occurred in 2010 when [[Prince Charles]] was greatly amused by a performance of the tune "[[Over the Rainbow]]" on an instrument recreated using [[squeaky toy]] cats by [[Henry Dagg]] for a [[garden party]] held at [[Clarence House]] supporting Charles's [[Start Initiative|Start]] initiative for sustainable living.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11273342 |title=Prince Charles' laughter over 'cat organ' |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=11 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1310898/Prince-Charles-interviewed-Daybreak-Adrian-Chiles-Christine-Bleakley.html |title=Please stop, one's sides are splitting! |first=Fay|last=Schlesing |date=11 September 2010 |journal=[[Daily Mail]]}}</ref>
In 2009, [[The People's Republic of Animation]], a professional animation studio, released an animation titled ''[[The Cat Piano]]''. This work tells the tale of a city of cats whose musicians are kidnapped by a human in order to make a cat piano. This short film has received several awards, as well as nominations for awards. The Academy announced that it was shortlisted for an Oscar for Best Animated Short. However, it was not nominated.
==See also== *[[Terry Jones]] – Monty Python's performer on a similar fictional instrument, the mouse organ (''Musical Mice'' sketch)<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F9nGyPz9uT0 Monty Python - mouse organ sketch] (YouTube) ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'', "Arthur Ewing and His Musical Mice," Season One, Episode Two.</ref> *[[Marvin Suggs]] – a character from ''[[The Muppet Show]]'' who plays a muppaphone *[[The Singing Dogs]] – a series of novelty recordings. *[[Donald Barthelme]] – The character Mr. Peterson, in the story "A shower of gold", is visited by a tall, foreign-looking man with a huge switchblade, who announces himself as the cat-piano player. *[[Keyboard Cat|Fatso]], a cat that played the piano *[[Rat king]]
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * Champfleury. ''Les Chats,'' Paris, 1870. *Calvete de Estrella, Juan Christobal (1930). ''El Felicisimo Viaje del Muy Alto y Muy Poderoso Principe Don Felipe'', p.73-7. Madrid: La Sociedad de Bibliofilos Espanoles. ** de Estrella, Juan Christoval Calvete (1552). ''El Felicissimo Viaje d'el Muy Alto y Muy poderoso Principe Don Phelippe''. Antwerp.
==External links== * [https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/72080522/ Interactive Katzenklavier], a project on [[Scratch (programming language)|scratch]] that has recently been featured (promoted on the front page).
[[Category:Cat equipment]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]] [[Category:Fictional musical instruments]] [[Category:Keyboard instruments]] [[Category:Zoomusicology]]

page.title: Causes of the vote in favour of Brexit

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} The result of the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|United Kingdom European Union Referendum of 2016]] was a victory for the "Leave" campaign, amassing a total of 51.9% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/25/world/europe/britain-brexit-european-union-referendum.html|title=Britain Votes to Leave E.U.; Cameron Plans to Step Down|last=Erlanger|first=Steven|date=23 June 2016|work=|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-07-15|via=}}</ref> This meant that the outcome was in favour of the [[United Kingdom]] to leaving the [[European Union]], a decision and process that has commonly referred to as "[[Brexit]]". Consequently, [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK Prime Minister]] [[Theresa May]] [[United Kingdom invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|triggered Article 50]] on 29 March 2017, starting the process of British withdrawal from the European Union.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/29/theresa-may-triggers-article-50-with-warning-of-consequences-for-uk|title=May triggers article 50 with warning of consequence for UK|last=Walker|first=Peter|last2=Asthana|first2=Anushka|date=2017-03-29|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-11-24|last3=Stewart|first3=Heather}}</ref>
The result provoked considerable debate as to the factors that contributed to the victory, with various theories and explanations being put forth. This page provides an overview of the different claims being made.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21702228-areas-lots-migrants-voted-mainly-remain-or-did-they-explaining-brexit-vote|title=Explaining the Brexit vote|last=|first=|date=16 July 2016|work=|newspaper=The Economist|issn=0013-0613|access-date=2016-07-15|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/politicsandpolicy/personal-values-brexit-vote/|title=It’s NOT the economy, stupid: Brexit as a story of personal values|last=|first=|date=7 July 2016|website=|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref>
== 'Leave' represented more popular positions == The 'Leave' campaign campaigned primarily on issues relating to sovereignty and migration,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-36375492|title=EU referendum: Vote Leave focuses on immigration|publisher=BBC News|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref> whereas the remain campaign focused on the economic impacts of leaving the EU. This choice of key positions is significant since [[Ipsos MORI]] survey data on which issues Britons felt to be 'important issues facing Britain today' shows that immediately prior to the vote, more people cited both the EU (32%) and migration (48%) as important issues than cited the economy (27%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ipsos-mori.com/researchpublications/researcharchive/3748/Concern-about-immigration-rises-as-EU-vote-approaches.aspx|title=Ipsos MORI {{!}} Poll {{!}} Concern about immigration rises as EU vote approaches|website=www.ipsos-mori.com|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref>
=== Sovereignty === {{Main|European Union law}} {{See also|Democratic deficit in the European Union}} On the day of the referendum [[Michael Ashcroft|Lord Ashcroft]]'s polling team questioned 12,369 people who had completed voting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lordashcroftpolls.com/2016/06/how-the-united-kingdom-voted-and-why/|title=How the United Kingdom voted on Thursday... and why - Lord Ashcroft Polls|website=lordashcroftpolls.com|access-date=2016-07-23}}</ref> This poll produced data that showed that 'Nearly half (49%) of leave voters said the biggest single reason for wanting to leave the [[European Union]] was “the principle that decisions about the UK should be taken in the UK”.
