| label1 = Formation | data1 = 18 May 1997 | label2 = Founder | data2 = MaNYaK | label3 = Membership | data3 = 12-men strong core group | label4 = Country | data4 = Turkey | label5 = Activity | data5 = Since 1997 | label6 = Category | data6 = Hacktivism, Activism | label7 = Website | data7 = http://redleaks.blogspot.com/
}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} '''Redhack''' ('''Kızıl Hackerlar''', '''Kızıl Hackerlar Birliği'''), is a [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[Marxism-Leninism|Marxist-Leninst]] [[hacker (computer security)|computer hacker]] group founded in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marxist RedHack Group Dumps Identities of Turkey's Police Informants Online|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/redhack-hackers-turkey-police-informants-anonymous-363377}}</ref> The group has claimed responsibility for hacking institutions which include the [[Council of Higher Education (Turkey)|Council of Higher Education]], Turkish police forces, the [[Turkish Land Forces|Turkish Army]], [[Türk Telekom]], and the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organization]] and many other websites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/?aType=haber&ArticleID=92699 |title=Groups hack MİT, TFF, police department's website | General | Worldbulletin News |publisher=Worldbulletin.net |date=2012-07-19 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> The group's core membership is said to number twelve; the leader's [[pseudonym]] is MaNYaK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/redhackin_lideri_sirin_baba_cikti-1086105 |title=RedHack'in lideri 'Şirin Baba' çıktı! - Türkiye Haberleri |publisher=Radikal |date=2012-04-26 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> RedHack is the first hacker group which has been accused of being a terrorist organization<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/redhack-turkey-terrorism-trial-056/ |title='Terrorist organization'? Turkish hackers face quarter-century prison terms — RT News |publisher=Rt.com |date=2012-10-10 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> and is currently one of the world's most wanted hacker groups.<ref>{{cite web|title=RedHack hacks into Turkey's Electric Distribution company website, delete bills worth 1.5 trillion Turkish Lira|url=http://www.techworm.net/2014/11/redhack-hacks-turkeys-electric-distribution-company-website-delete-bills-worth-1-5-trillion-turkish-lira.html}}</ref>
==Pre-2012==
* 1990: Hacking the international system of the Istanbul Police Department Traffic Services and erasing all fines.<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.wardom.org/redhack-istanbuldaki-trafik-cezalarini-sildi-161520/ |title=RedHack Istanbuldaki Trafik Cezalarini sildi |publisher=Wardom.org |date=2007-09-14 |accessdate=2014-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605051022/http://www.wardom.org/redhack-istanbuldaki-trafik-cezalarini-sildi-161520/ |archivedate=5 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * 2000: Hacking and decoding the CCTV system. * 2 July 2008: In memory of the [[Sivas massacre]] the group hacked and defaced 256 government and hundreds of fascist websites, the Ministry of the Interior was also under the affected websites.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://istanbul.indymedia.org/tr/news/2008/07/241783.php |title=RedHack Sivas Eylemi Sonuc Bildirisi: "Sanal Devleti Yiktik!" |language=tr |publisher=İstanbul Indymedia |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605052722/http://istanbul.indymedia.org/tr/news/2008/07/241783.php |archivedate=5 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * 2 July 2011: Hacking and defacing the more than 1000 websites,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pastebin.com/EeHGHj8g |title=EeHGHj8g |publisher=www.pastebin.com |date=2011-07-02 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> among them websites of Adnan Oktar and fascist websites in memory of the Sivas massacre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haber.sol.org.tr/bilim-teknoloji/redhack-2-temmuz-icin-hackledi-haberi-44196 |title=RedHack 2 Temmuz için hackledi | soL Haber Portalı |publisher=Haber.sol.org.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
==2012==
* 22 February 2012: After taking down 350 police websites, the group leaked internal data.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/tutuklu_redhack_350_siteyi_hackledi-1083334 |title='Tutuklu' RedHack 350 siteyi hack'ledi - Türkiye Haberleri |publisher=Radikal |date=2012-03-30 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 6 March 2012: 900 record numbers, names, email addresses and passwords belonging to the staffers of Turkey’s National Police have been published online by the group. The group commented "We also held a grudge against Ankara police for their brutality against Tekel workers and their arbitrary blacklisting of citizens. Everyone can forget, but communists do not."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Leaks-Data-from-Turkish-National-Police-256902.shtml |title=RedHack Leaks Data from Turkish National Police |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 22 April 2012: A subpage of the Ministry of Interior of Turkey was defaced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/redhack-takes-down-turkish-interior-ministry-website-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=18894&NewsCatID=374 |title=Redhack takes down Turkish Interior Ministry website - SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2011-09-13 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 27 April 2012: As a result of a DDoS attack the Turkish ISP TTNet internet slows down. The spokesman of the Presidency of Telecommunication and Communication confirmed this attack, but denied any damage on the infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ekonomi.haberturk.com/teknoloji/haber/737813-internet-neden-kesildi |title=Türkiye'de internet kesintisi, İstanbul, internet yavaş, internette kesinti, TTNET, Redhack, Türk Telekom - En Son Teknoloji Haberleri - HTEkonomi |publisher=Ekonomi.haberturk.com |date=2012-04-27 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 2 May 2012: With hacking into the system of the Land Force Command, the group leaked information of personnel of the Turkish Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internethaber.com/redhack-kara-kuvvetleri-komutanligi-personel-kizil-hackerlar--433551h.htm |title=Haber : Redhack yaptı yine yapacağını! haberi |publisher=Internethaber.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 3 May 2012: In reaction to the poisoning of pupil which started with the project of the Ministry of Education, the group hacked the websites of the responsible supplying milk companies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mynet |url=http://www.mynet.com/haber/guncel/bozuk-sute-redhack-tepki-verdi-628688-1 |title=Bozuk Süte Redhack Tepki Verdi Haberi ve Son Dakika Haberler Mynet |publisher=Mynet.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 14 May 2012: On Mother's Day the group hacked and defaced the website of the Ministry of Family Affairs and left a message which criticized the level of women rights in Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/aile-bakanligi-ni-redhack-hackledi/gundem/gundemdetay/14.05.2012/1539999/default.htm |title=Aile Bakanlığı'nı RedHack hackledi - Milliyet Haber |publisher=Milliyet.com.tr |date=2012-05-14 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 29 May 2012: In support of the strike the group took down the website of Turkish Airlines. The current Minister of the Ministry of Transport, Maritime and Communication Binali Yıldırım confirmed the attack but denied any damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnturk.com/2012/bilim.teknoloji/teknoloji/05/29/thynin.resmi.sitesi.hacklendi/662895.0/index.html |title=THY'nin resmi sitesi hacklendi - CNN TÜRK |publisher=Cnnturk.com |date=2012-05-29 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 3 July 2012: The group targeted and file sharing system of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, disclosed the IDs of foreign diplomats. It is worth mentioning that the group was also able to steal 65 gigabyte of internal files, which have not been leaked so far.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/redhack-discloses-ids-of-foreign-diplomats-in-turkey-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=24617&NewsCatID=374 |title=RedHack discloses IDs of foreign diplomats in Turkey - SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2011-09-13 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 16 July 2012: As a reaction to the threats against journalists and academics who supported RedHack, the group leaked a 77 megabyte txt file which was stolen on 22 February 2012 from the internal system of the Ankara Security Directorate and revealed identities of Turkish police informants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Reveals-Identities-of-Turkish-Police-Informants-281442.shtml |title=RedHack Reveals Identities of Turkish Police Informants |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2012-07-16 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 29 October 2012: With hacking and defacing the website of the Presidency of Religious Affairs, the group left a message to criticize the government and Fethullah Gülen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bianet.org/bianet/bilisim/141716-redhack-diyaneti-hackledi |title=RedHack Diyanet'i Hackledi |publisher=bianet |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 2 October 2012: With hacking the website of the Public Procurement Authority, released a bid on the website to sell Justice and Development Party for 1 cent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/21837936.asp |title=RedHack, KİK'in sitesine saldırdı - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 7 December 2012: Hacking the system of the Ministry of Finance, the group announced the increasing of raise for officers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/-redhack-ten-memura-zam-/gundem/gundemdetay/07.12.2012/1638265/default.htm |title='RedHack'ten memura zam! - Milliyet Haber |publisher=Milliyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 25 December 2012: With the "help" of the group the government was able to arrest pedophilia, also Twitter accounts were suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/planet/22228243.asp |title=Pedofilleri Türk hacker'lar yakalattı - Hürriyet PLANET |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date=2012-12-25 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
==2013==
* 8 January 2013: With hacking the Council of Higher Education for a second time, the group stole more than 60.000 files. With the start of the leaking more and more files the group proofed the cases of corruption at various educational institutions, including Istanbul University, the Uludağ University in Bursa, Marmara University, and Çukurova University and many more universities around Turkey. Just a few days before this breach, the Council of Higher Education denied to be part of the cyber attack test by the Presidency of Telecommunication and Communication.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Turkey-s-Council-of-Higher-Education-Hacked-by-RedHack-60-000-Documents-Leaked-319958.shtml |title=Turkey's Council of Higher Education Hacked by RedHack, 60,000 Documents Leaked |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 26 February 2013: The group leaked files about the Mayor of the Ankara Metropolitan Melih Gökçek. This included personal information as well as assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnturk.com/2013/guncel/02/27/redhackten.sok.melih.gokcek.belgeleri/698087.0/ |title=Redhack'ten şok Melih Gökçek belgeleri - CNN TÜRK |publisher=Cnnturk.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 22 March 2013: In support of RedHack Anonymous took down the website of the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ankara/22875503.asp |title=Pekin'de panda pazarlığı - Hürriyet Ankara Anasayfa |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 23 March 2013: In cooperation with Anonymous the group has been able to take down the [[Mossad]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/teknoloji/22877072.asp |title=İsrail gizli servisi çöktü - Hürriyet TEKNOLOJİ |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date=2013-03-23 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 5 May 2013: In reaction to the Istanbul Governorship's brutal actions against the protesters on May day in Turkey, the group defaced the website of the Istanbul Governorship and left a message for the Governor Vali Mutlu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/23213121.asp |title=Redhack İstanbul Valiliği'ni hackledi - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 11 May 2013: As a reaction to the bombings in Reyhanlı, Hatay, the group took down the Hatay Governor for mourning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/23261048.asp |title=Redhack'ten 'Ulusal yas' tepkisi - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 22 May 2013: The group published documents about the attack, and claimed that they belong to Gendarmerie Intelligence Department. The documents indicate that the bombing was planned by Al-Qaeda related rebel groups in Syria, contrary to government's claims. JDP vice president Hüseyin Çelik stated that the documents were not obtained by hacking but leaked, and that their content is not related to Reyhanlı bombings but to another unrelated one, for which precautions are made. On 24 May private Utku Kali was arrested, charged with leaking the documents. RedHack denied any involvement of Kali. Kali was released on 11 November.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/05/secret-military-documents-of-turkeys-reyhanli-explosion-was-hacked-and-leaked-online-by-redhack.html |title=Secret Military Documents of Turkey's Reyhanli explosion was hacked and Leaked online by RedHack |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 26 May 2013: Mail correspondence of the current Minister for EU Affairs Egemen Bağış leaked.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mayıs 28, 2013 |url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2013/gundem/redhackten-son-bomba-302268/ |title=Redhack'ten son bomba- Sözcü Gazetesi |publisher=Sozcu.com.tr |date=2013-05-28 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 1 June 2013: In order to protest the silence against the Turkish MPs, the group leaked the telephone numbers of the MPs and their spouses<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haber.gazetevatan.com/redhack-vekilleri-hackledi/542840/1/gundem |title=Redhack' vekilleri hackledi! | GAZETE VATAN |publisher=Haber.gazetevatan.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> on their blog.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://redleaks.blogspot.de/2013/06/tbmm-milletvekili-ve-esleri-telefon-numaralari.html |title=#RedLeaks RedHack Belgeleri.. Kizil Hackerlar - 1997-2013: TBMM çalışanları, Milletvekilleri ve Eşlerinin Ev, Cep, işyeri Numaralari - RedHack |publisher=Redleaks.blogspot.de |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> This was just the start of a long history of hacks under the banner #OpTurkey, which is a collaboration between [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] and RedHack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bianet.org/english/world/147191-anonymous-supports-gezi-resistance |title=Anonymous Supports Gezi Resistance - english |publisher=Bianet.org |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 8 June 2013: To protest the police brutality regarding the protesters, the group leaked the telephone numbers of all provincial police chiefs in Istanbul. The leak contained also an internal message that police officers were responsible to save every intervention digital with a camera.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/istanbul-emniyeti-ni-redhack-vurdu/gundem/detay/1720172/default.htm |title=İstanbul Emniyeti'ni Redhack vurdu - Milliyet Haber |publisher=Milliyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 12 June 2013: As a reaction to the death of Ethem Sarisülük who got shot by a police officer, RedHack took down the website of the Ankara Police Department.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/06/police-department-website-of-ankara-capital-of-turkey-has-been-taken-down-by-redhack.html |title=Police Department Website of Ankara (Capital of Turkey) has been taken down by REDHACK |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 17 June 2013: The group leaked an audio which contained a meeting between the Minister of Agriculture and businessmen.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rURcGRrJVYo |title=Tarım Bakanı, AKP'liler ve İş Adamları Arasında Geçen Toplantın Ses Kaydı - RedHack |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 28 June 2013: The group hacked the Istanbul Special Provincial Administration, leaked user information and called on its followers to feel free to change things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/teknoloji/23604713.asp?top=1 |title=RedHack, İl Özel İdare'yi hackledi - Hürriyet TEKNOLOJİ |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 2 July 2013: The group hacked and successfully took down the website of the Sivas Special Provincial Administration to commemorate the Sivas massacre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haber.sol.org.tr/devlet-ve-siyaset/redhack-sivas-katliami-icin-hackledi-haberi-75681 |title=Redhack Sivas Katliamı için hackledi | soL Haber Portalı |publisher=Haber.sol.org.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 3 July 2013: The group hacked the Presidency of Religious Affairs, leaked the user information and called on its followers on Twitter to fell free to change things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/teknoloji/23641465.asp |title=Şimdi de Diyanet'i hacklediler - Hürriyet TEKNOLOJİ |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 14 August 2013: The group hacked the Adana Metropolitan Municipality Water and Sewerage Authority, leaked the user information and called on its followers to feel free to change things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/24527771.asp |title=Adana'da RedHack alarmı - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 23 August 2013: Hacking the website of the Union of Municipalities of Turkey and leaking out the usernames and passwords. The attack is dedicated to one of the Gezi protest victims Ali İsmail Korkmaz and Utku Kali, who in their mind has not leaked the documents regarding the Reyhanli bombings and is not a member of the group.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/08/redhacks-latest-victim-union-municipalities-turkey-login-credentials-leaked.html |title=RedHack's latest victim is Union of Municipalities of Turkey, login credentials leaked |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 5 September 2013: The group took down the website of the Turkish National Police to remind law enforcement the victims of the Gezi protest and Dilan Alp, who was seriously injured by police on May Day in Istanbul.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/09/turkish-police-website-working-anymore-redhack-taken.html |title=Turkish Police website not working anymore after the RedHack taken that DOWN |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 11 September 2013: The releasing of documents with the name of police officers who killed Turkish Protester [[Abdullah Comert|Abdullah Cömert]], who was one of the victims of police brutality during the Gezi protest. The leak contained the names of police officers, their location, dates and time.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/09/redhack-released-documents-name-police-officers-killed-turkish-protester-abdullah.html |title=RedHack released documents with the name of police officers who killed Turkish Protester 'Abdullah' |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 14 October 2013: The group hacked and defaced the website of the [[Turkish Union of Public Enterprises|Turkey Union of Public Enterprises]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teknofiber.net/2013/10/redhackten-bayram-mesaji.html |title=Redhack Bayram Mesajını Hack Yaparak Verdi! |publisher=Teknofiber.net |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 22 October 2013: The group released 18 documents related to Turkey’s former Minister for EU Affairs Egemen Bağış on the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] network. Besides Bağış’ income, communications with foreign officials, daily activities, and official meetings the documents also exposed the misusing of his authority.<ref>{{cite web|author=Praveen Kashyap |url=http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/10/redhack-exposes-documents-related-turkeys-minister-eu-affairs.html |title=RedHack exposes documents related to Turkey's Minister for EU Affairs |location=United States |publisher=Hackersnewsbulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 25 November 2013: While 14 people were behind bars accused of being members of the group, RedHack hacked and left a message on the website of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kasım 25, 2013 |url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2013/gundem/redhack-akpyi-hackledi-413236/ |title=Redhack AKP'yi hackledi!- Sözcü Gazetesi |publisher=Sozcu.com.tr |date=2013-11-25 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 2 December 2013: In response to the repeated arrest of Taylan, RedHack breached and defaced the website of [[Justice and Development Party of Ordu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Site-of-Turkey-s-Ruling-Party-Hacked-After-Arrest-of-Alleged-RedHack-Member-405035.shtml |title=Site of Turkey's Ruling Party Hacked After Arrest of Alleged RedHack Member |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2013-12-02 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
==2014==
* 10 January 2014: The group hacked the website of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey and left the message "RedHack, hack for the public."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odatv.com/n.php?n=redhack-bu-kez-tbmmyi-hackledi-1001141200 |title=Redhack bu kez TBMM'yi hackledi |publisher=Odatv.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> The group also leaked phone numbers of turkcell employees in response to the changing of phone numbers of the high ranked government officials which they leaked a few hours ago.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Leaks-Phone-Numbers-of-Turkcell-Employees-417692.shtml |title=RedHack Leaks Phone Numbers of Turkcell Employees |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-01-16 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 11 January 2014: The group exploited a cross-site scripting vulnerability on the Parliament’s website to send a message to the government, breached the website of the [[Turkish State Railways]] and leaked several files allegedly stolen from the organization’s systems, leaked usernames and clear text passwords from the [[Turkish Contractors Association]]. The group was also able to infiltrate the email systems of the AKP Izmir headquarters and leaked emails that represented acts of corruption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Hacks-Turkish-Contractors-Association-and-State-Railways-415876.shtml |title=RedHack Hacks Turkish Contractors Association and State Railways |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-01-11 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 16 January 2014: In response to the inaction of the Central Bank the group took down the website of the Central Bank of Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Website-of-Turkey-s-Central-Bank-Disrupted-by-RedHack-417821.shtml |title=Website of Turkey's Central Bank Disrupted by RedHack |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-01-16 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 4 February 2014: The group breached the systems of three major telecoms companies, TTNET, [[Turkcell]], and [[Vodafone]]. The leaked data included names, dates of birth, phone numbers, and voicemail delivery details. Addresses were not published as a matter of principle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btnet.com.tr/90144-redhack-turkcell-vodafone-ve-ttnetin-kullanici-bilgilerini-ele-gecirdi.html |title=RedHack Turkcell, Vodafone ve TTNET'e sızdı | BTnet Teknoloji Haber Portali |publisher=Btnet.com.tr |date=2014-02-03 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> Especially the data from Vodafone showed that the company is logging voicemails.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Leaks-Details-of-5-000-Vodafone-Customers-423862.shtml |title=RedHack Leaks Data from Vodafone to Show That the Company Is Logging Voicemails |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-02-04 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Leaks-the-Details-of-Turkish-Officials-After-Hacking-Major-Telecoms-Firms-423526.shtml |title=RedHack Leaks the Details of Turkish Officials After Hacking Major Telecoms Firms |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 6 February 2014: Leaking the phone numbers of some MPs of the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egeninsesi.com/137532-redhack_akpli_vekillerin_telefon_numaralarini_verdi |title=RedHack AKP'li Vekillerin Telefon Numaralarını Verdi |publisher=Egeninsesi.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 8 February 2014: Leaking the phone numbers of police officers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://egeninsesi.com/137763-redhack_polislerin_telefon_numaralarini_yayinladi |title=RedHack Polislerin Telefon Numaralarını Yayınladı |publisher=Egeninsesi.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 10 February 2014: In response to the new internet law the group leaked the phone numbers of police officers. Then they defaced the official website of the Kars Municipality and left a message in protest against the new Internet law. The website of the Gas Distribution Authority of Sakarya was also hacked with the comment "gas is free because the corrupt government is stealing enough from the people".The third target on that day has been the website of the City of Amasya, from which the group leaked the Justice and Development Party's membership applications. Also the Ministry of Education was also attacked, its voices and the expenditures of schools have been published online on [[JustPaste.It]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Begins-Hack-Attacks-in-Protest-Against-Turkey-s-New-Internet-Law-425418.shtml |title=RedHack Begins Hack Attacks in Protest Against Turkey's New Internet Law |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-02-10 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 12 February 2014: The group leaked the contact information for 36 staff members of the US Embassy in Turkey. The leak contained a list of names, email addresses, job titles and phone numbers. It was dedicated to [[Sinan Cemgil]], one of the founders of [[Turkish People’s Liberation Army]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Leaks-Contact-Information-of-US-Embassy-Staff-426336.shtml |title=RedHack Leaks Contact Information of US Embassy Staff |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-02-12 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 28 March 2014: In response to the decision to ban YouTube and Twitter in Turkey, the group took down the website of the Presidency of Telecommunication and Communication of Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Website-of-Turkey-s-Telecommunications-Directorate-Attacked-by-RedHack-434637.shtml |title=Website of Turkey's Telecommunications Directorate Attacked by RedHack |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-03-28 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 18 April 2014: As a reaction to the new controversial e-ticketing system for soccer games, the group hacked and also took down the website of Aktif Bank.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Hackers-Target-Aktif-Bank-over-Controversial-e-Ticketing-System-438409.shtml |title=RedHack Hackers Target Aktif Bank over Controversial e-Ticketing System |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-04-18 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 19 May 2014: RedHack breached the official website of the Turkish Cooperation and Coordination Agency,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tika.gov.tr|title=TİKA - Turkish Cooperation and Coordination Agency - TİKA|website=tika.gov.tr}}</ref> an organization operating under the Prime Ministry of the Republic of Turkey and leaked the usernames and clear-text passwords belonging to the site’s users. The hackers have told TechWorm that the attack is dedicated to İbrahim Kaypakkaya, who was a major leader of the Communist movement in Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Turkish-Cooperation-and-Coordination-Agency-Hacked-by-RedHack-442797.shtml |title=Turkish Cooperation and Coordination Agency Hacked by RedHack |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date=2014-05-19 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 28 May 2014: Hijacking the email account of the Manisa MP [[Muzaffer Yurttaş]] from the Justice and Development Party and leaking internal chats regarding the Soma mine disaster, which showed that not only the high percentage of carbon monoxide was the cause for the deaths, also claims of dynamite usage came to light.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/redhackten-soma-iddiasi-dinamit-patlatildi-kablolardan-yangin-cikti,259673 |title=Redhack'ten Soma iddiası: Dinamit patlatıldı, kablolardan yangın çıktı - Gündem |publisher=T24 |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 30 May 2014: Hacking into the email account, leaking chats, hijacking the Twitter and Facebook account of the Prime Minister's chiefadvisor Mustafa Varank. The group shared a comment on Twitter<ref>{{cite tweet|user=TheRedHack|author=RedHack ★|number=472122732331556864|date=29 May 2014|title=Başbakanın ABD'den 'Bilgisayar Bilimleri' mezunu Başdanışmanı hacklenmiştir. Artık gelsin bize danışsın! #RedHack}}</ref> "The Prime Minister Chiefadvisor who graduated in Computer Science in the United States of America has been hacked. Come and consult us now!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odatv.com/n.php?n=basbakanin-danismanina-redhack-soku-3005141200 |title=Başbakan'ın danışmanına Redhack şoku |publisher=Odatv.com |date=2014-05-30 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 1 June 2014: In the early morning the group successfully hacked and defaced the website of the Ankara Chamber of Industry (ASO) and left a message against the Nuclear Power Summit.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waqas |url=http://hackread.com/redhack-anonymous-hacks-turkey/ |title=RedHack hacks Ankara Chamber of Industry website against Nuclear Summit |publisher=Hack Read |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> The group was also able to hack and relink the website of the Trabzon Provincial Special Administration to a pastehtml script.<ref>http://pastehtml.com/view/e8fw1t4dm.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sendika.org/2014/06/redhack-nukleerci-ankara-sanayi-odasinin-sitesini-hackledi/ |title=Redhack nükleerci Ankara Sanayi Odası'nın sitesini hackledi – |publisher=Sendika.org |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 1 June 2014: Later the same day the website of the Tunceli Governor's Office with its SODES Project Coordination Centre was hacked and a message was left calling on the government to punish pedophiles, as an example the rape of a kid was mentioned in which the group accused the government and the ruling party in concealing the rape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Hacks-Governor-s-Office-in-Tunceli-Urges-Govt-to-Punish-Child-Abuse-444807.shtml |title=RedHack Hacks Site of Governor's Office in Tunceli, Urges Govt to Punish Child Abuse |publisher=News.softpedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * 14 June 2014: Breached the email account of Izzet Artunç, head of the Turkish Mechanical and Chemical Industry Company.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://news.softpedia.com/news/RedHack-Hijacks-Email-Account-of-Chief-of-Military-Industry-Company-Controlled-by-Govt-446807.shtml|title = RedHack Hijacks Email Account of Chief of Military Industry Company Controlled by Turkish Govt|date = 14 June 2014|accessdate = 15 June 2014|website = Softpedia|publisher = |last = Vatu|first = Gabriela}}</ref>
==Arrests== On 23 March 2012: Seven of 17 people have been arrested as a result of an operation by the Ankara Chief Public Prosecutor of the Special Authority against RedHack. The group claimed in a statement that those arrested had no ties with the group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bianet.org/bianet/bianet/137088-redhack-orgutunden-yedi-tutuklama |title=RedHack "Örgütünden" Yedi Tutuklama |publisher=bianet |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 5 July 2012: The public prosecutor made an application to evaluate RedHack as a "armed separatist terrorist organization".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/redhack_resmen_teror_orgutu_ilan_edildi-1093352 |title=Redhack resmen terör örgütü ilan edildi - Türkiye Haberleri |publisher=Radikal |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 8 October 2012: The application from 5 July was accepted and the public prosecutor has requested a penalty of about 8.5 to 24 years for alleged members. There were still 3 students in detention after four of seven arrested people were released. The case was postponed to 26 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/savci_e_devlete_saldiri_da_terordur-1103345 |title=Savcı: E-devlet'e saldırı da terördür - Türkiye Haberleri |publisher=Radikal |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 26 November 2012: Three students accused of being a member of the group were released. The court postponed the case to 26 February 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/797773-redhack-davasinda-karar |title=RedHack üyesi olduğu iddiasıyla tutuklan ve 24 yıl hapis cezası-En Son Güvenlik Haberleri-HABERTÜRK |publisher=Haberturk.com |date=2012-11-26 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 26 February 2013: The court decided to postpone the case to 3 June 2013. Reason for this was that the chief justice was still searching for "experts which are needed for the IT part of the case".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/22686027.asp |title=Bilirkişi bulamadılar - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date=2013-02-26 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 9 May 2013: The Ankara Deputy Attorney General stated under the Anti-Terrorism Act that the actions of RedHack "did not involve violence" and with the lack of jurisdiction the Attorney General passed the case to the Cyber Crimes Investigation Unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/23242468.asp |title=Savcılık: "RedHack terör örgütü değil" - Hürriyet GÜNDEM |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
On 25 May 2013: After the group's leaking of classified documents which proved the Turkish government's carelessness of the Reyhanli bombings on 11 May, Private Utku Kali, who was serving at that time at the Amasya Commands, was arrested. After Kali denied being a member of the hacktivist group and leaking the documents, he was released. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://bianet.org/bianet/siyaset/146995-reyhanli-belgeleri-nobet-saatine-denk-geldi-diye-tutuklandi |title="Reyhanlı Belgeleri Nöbet Saatine Denk Geldi" Diye Tutuklandı - Ayça Söylemez |publisher=bianet |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>

{{citation style|date=August 2010}} [[Image:RTU Logo.png|200px|thumb|The 2006 Logo for Rock the Universe]] '''Rock the Universe''' is an annual [[Christian rock festival]] that takes place at [[Universal Studios Florida]]. It started in 1998, and it used to take place in September. Since 2019, the festival is celebrated on the first weekend of February. The festival has had three stages over the years. The main one is located on the entrance for the Rip, Ride, and Rock It roller coaster. The ''Hollywood Stage'' is by the Central Park area and the lake, close to the middle of the park. {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Royal Caledonian Ball | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = Royal Caledonian Ball logo.png | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | status = | genre = Charity ball | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | venue = [[Grosvenor House Hotel]] | location = 86-90 Park Lane
London W1K 7TN | coordinates = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | years_active = | first = {{Start date|1849}} | founder_name = [[George Murray, 6th Duke of Atholl|George, Duke of Atholl]]
[[Anne Murray, Duchess of Atholl|Anne, Duchess of Atholl]] | last = 4 May 2018 | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = 1,300+ (record set in 1980s) | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]]; [[Anne, Princess Royal]]; [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent]] and [[Katharine, Duchess of Kent]] | organised = Royal Caledonian Ball Trust Committee | filing = | people = [[Charles Hay, 16th Earl of Kinnoull|Charles, Earl of Kinnoull]] (president)
[[Merlin Hay, 24th Earl of Erroll|Merlin, Earl of Erroll]] (vice president) | member = | sponsor = | website = {{URL|royalcaledonianball.com}} | footnotes = }} The '''Royal Caledonian Ball''' is a [[Ball (dance party)|ball]] held annually in London for the benefit of Scottish charities. With few exceptions, the Royal Caledonian Ball has been held annually since 1849, and is the oldest charity ball in the world.{{cite news|last1=Ross|first1=Peter|title=The Royal Caledonian Ball keeps it reel in London|url=http://www.scotsman.com/what-s-on/theatre-comedy-dance/the-royal-caledonian-ball-keeps-it-reel-in-london-1-2926441|accessdate=1 April 2015|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=12 May 2013}} It is considered the highlight of the [[Season (society)|London season]].{{cite news|title=Plenty of space to swing your sporran|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/plenty-of-space-to-swing-your-sporran-1-532354|accessdate=1 April 2015|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=23 May 2004}} ==History== The ball dates to the 1840s, when [[George Murray, 6th Duke of Atholl|George, Duke of Atholl]] and his wife [[Anne Murray, Duchess of Atholl|Anne]] wanted to entertain their Scottish friends residing in London.Clark McGinn, ''The Ultimate Guide to Being Scottish: Put Your First Foot Forward'', Luath Press, 2014, p. 245 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e7JD-WoRojoC&pg=PA245&dq=%22Royal+Caledonian+Ball%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Hg3RVIO2Jov8ywPjlYFo&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Royal%20Caledonian%20Ball%22&f=false] By 1849, it had become a fundraiser for Scottish charities helping vulnerable schoolchildren, the homeless, and cancer patients. The Royal Caledonian Ball has been held every year, except during the [[Second Boer War|Boer War]], [[World War I]] and [[World War II]], and following the death of King [[Edward VII]] on 6 May 1910. The ball has been under the royal patronage since Edward VII. Since the 1930s, the event has been held at the [[Grosvenor House Hotel]] on [[Park Lane, London]].{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.royalcaledonianball.com/history/|publisher=Royal Caledonian Ball|accessdate=1 April 2015}} The Queen is often in attendance. In recent years, the ball has been featured in the ''Bystander'' section of ''[[Tatler]]''.[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2008/july/the-royal-caledonian-ball#!/2099/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: Royal Caledonian Ball], ''[[Tatler]]'', 1 July 2008[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2009/june/the-royal-caledonian-ball#!/2032/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: Royal Caledonian Ball], ''[[Tatler]]'', 1 June 2009[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2010/june/the-royal-caledonian-ball#!/1923/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: Royal Caledonian Ball], ''[[Tatler]]'', 1 June 2010[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2012/june/the-royal-caledonian-ball#!/7427/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: Royal Caledonian Ball], ''[[Tatler]]'', 8 June 2012[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2013/july/royal-caledonian-ball#!/11431/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: Royal Caledonian Ball], '''''Tatler''''', 16 July 2013[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2014/july/the-caledonian-ball#!/14824/image/1 Bystander: Mayfair: The Caledonian Ball], ''[[Tatler]]'', 22 July 2014Sophia Money-Coutts, [http://www.tatler.com/news/articles/september-2014/the-future-of-scotland The Future of Scotland?], ''[[Tatler]]'', 8 December 2014 ==Dance and dress== The Royal Caledonian Ball [[dress code]] stipulates that male attendees wear [[Highland dress#Highland formal wear|Highland evening dress]], evening tails with [[white tie]], or [[mess dress]]. Women should wear floor-length evening dress or mess dress; [[tartan]] sashes are encouraged. The event is known for its [[Scottish country dance|Scottish country dancing]], and it is traditional for ball attendees to dance every [[Reel (dance)|reel]]:{{cite web|title=The Reels|url=http://www.royalcaledonianball.com/reels/|publisher=Royal Caledonian Ball|accessdate=1 April 2015}} {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Dashing White Sergeant]] * [[Reel of the 51st Highlanders]] * Eightsome Reel * Foursome Reel * [[Mairi's Wedding]] * [[Hamilton House (dance)|Hamilton House]] * [[Duke of Perth (reel)|Duke of Perth]] * Inverness Country Dance * The Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh * Quickstep * D'ye ken John Peel }} Traditionally, the [[Duke of Atholl|Duke]] and Duchess of Atholl are the first couple to start the dance, followed by his private army, the [[Atholl Highlanders]].'Royal Caledonian Ball: Regimental Reels for Reels', ''[[The Glasgow Herald]]'', 22 April 1963 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19630422&id=smxAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kaMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3705,3542537] Moreover, men wore full evening [[tartan]] while women were dressed in while, with a tartan sash.Angela Lambert, ''1939: The Last Season of Peace'', [[A & C Black]], 2011 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=q8GZ2yUhvQQC&pg=PT98&dq=%22Royal+Caledonian+Ball%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Hg3RVIO2Jov8ywPjlYFo&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Royal%20Caledonian%20Ball%22&f=false] Indeed, it was the only socially acceptable opportunity to wear full tartan outside Scotland. ==Charities== The ball supports numerous charities in Scotland and has raised an estimated £3 million since its inception.{{cite news|title=London’s Royal Caledonian Ball supports small Scottish charities|url=http://www.theedinburghreporter.co.uk/2013/11/londons-royal-caledonian-ball-supports-small-scottish-charities/|accessdate=1 April 2015|work=The Edinburgh Reporter|date=14 November 2013}} Among the charities the ball supports are [[Queen Victoria School]] in [[Dunblane]], [[Erskine (charity)|Erskine Hospital]], and St Catherine’s Homeless Project in [[Edinburgh]]. ==References== {{about|the Second Cairo Conference of December 4–6, 1943, between the United States, the United Kingdom and the Republic of Turkey|the First Cairo Conference of November 22–26, 1943, between the United States, the United Kingdom and the Republic of China|Cairo Conference}}
[[File:Roosevelt Inönü and Churchill in Cairo cph.3b15312.jpg|thumb|240px|[[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]], [[Ismet Inönü|İnönü]] and [[Winston Churchill|Churchill]] at the Second Cairo Conference, which was held between December 4–6, 1943.]]
The '''Second Cairo Conference''' of December 4–6, 1943, held in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], addressed [[Turkey]]'s possible contribution to the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] in [[World War II]].<ref name=Matloff>[http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/sp1943-44/chapter16.htm U.S. Army: "Strategic Planning for Coalition Warfare, 1943-1944" by Maurice Matloff, Chapter XVI, pp. 379-380.] Center of Military History, United States Army, Washington D.C., 1990. Library of Congress Catalog Card Number 53-61477. First Printed 1959-CMH Pub 1-4.</ref> The meeting was attended by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] of the [[United States]], Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]] of the [[United Kingdom]], and President [[İsmet İnönü]] of the [[Turkey|Republic of Turkey]].<ref name=Matloff/>
Until 1941, both Roosevelt and Churchill maintained the opinion that Turkey's continuing neutrality would serve the interests of the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] by blocking the [[Axis powers of World War II|Axis]] from reaching the strategic oil reserves of the [[Middle East]]. But the early victories of the Axis until the end of 1942 caused Roosevelt and Churchill to re-evaluate a possible Turkish participation in the war on the side of the Allies.<ref name=Matloff/> Turkey had maintained a decently-sized Army and Air Force throughout the war, and especially Churchill wanted the Turks to open a new front in the [[Balkans]].<ref name=Matloff/> On January 30, 1943, Churchill had secretly met with İnönü inside a train wagon at the Yenice Station, 23 kilometers outside of [[Adana]] in [[Turkey]], to discuss the issue (see the [[Adana Conference]].)<ref name=Matloff/>
Roosevelt, on the other hand, still believed that a Turkish attack would be too risky and an eventual Turkish failure would have disastrous effects for the Allies.<ref name=Matloff/>
İnönü knew very well the hardships which his country had to suffer during 11 years of incessant war (the [[Italo-Turkish War]], the [[Balkan Wars]], the [[World War I|First World War]], and the [[Turkish War of Independence]]) between 1911 and 1922, and was determined to keep Turkey out of another war as long as he could. İnönü also wanted assurances on financial and military aid for Turkey, as well as a guarantee that the [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]] would stand beside Turkey in case of a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] invasion of the [[Turkish Straits]] after the war, as [[Joseph Stalin]] had openly expressed.<ref name=Matloff/> The fear of a Soviet invasion and Stalin's unconcealed desire to control the [[Turkish Straits]] eventually caused Turkey to give up its principle of [[neutrality (international relations)|neutrality in foreign relations]] and join [[NATO]] in 1952.
[[File:Second Cairo Conference.jpg|thumb|240px|Roosevelt and İnönü got what they wanted, while Churchill was a bit disappointed of the result.]]
Perhaps the biggest reason for Turkey's hesitation to immediately join the war on the side of the Allies was the eventual reduction of the amount of financial and military aid which Churchill had promised in Adana.<ref name=Matloff/> By December 1943 the Anglo-American authorities felt the overall situation had changed so fundamentally that a much smaller scale of assistance than that provided in the Hardihood Agreement of the spring of 1943 would be necessary.<ref name=Matloff/> The British proposed a reduced scale of Aid Plan Saturn.<ref name=Matloff/> The Turks, on the other hand, wished to make certain that upon their entry into the war they would be strong enough to defend their homeland and they doubted that the new plan would fully meet their security needs.<ref name=Matloff/> Churchill, faced with [[Operation Overlord]] only six months away, reluctantly concluded that the resources demanded and the time required for strengthening Turkey could not be conceded.<ref name=Matloff/> The U.S. Chiefs of Staff and their planners, on the other hand, felt relieved that this possible threat to concentration on Operation Overlord had at last been removed.<ref name=Matloff/>
At the end of the conference, it was decided that Turkey's neutrality should be maintained.<ref name=Matloff/> It was also decided to build the [[Incirlik Air Base]] near Adana for possible [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] air operations in the region, but construction works began after the end of the Second World War.<ref name=Matloff/> Incirlik Air Base later played an important role for [[NATO]] during the [[Cold War]]. Another decision was to postpone Operation Anakim against [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] in [[Burma]].<ref name=Matloff/>
Both Roosevelt and İnönü got what they wanted, while Churchill was a bit disappointed, because he believed that an active Turkish participation in the war would quicken the German defeat by hitting their ''"soft underbelly"'' in the southeast.
Turkey eventually joined the war on the side of the Allies on 23 February 1945, after it was announced at the [[Yalta Conference]] that only the states which were formally at war with [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] and [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] by 1 March 1945 would be admitted to the [[United Nations]].<ref>Mustafa Aydın, SAM, "Turkish Foreign Policy: Framework and Analysis", Center for Strategic Research, 2004, p. 47.</ref> However, Turkey didn't directly participate in a military conflict; limiting its participation to providing materials and supplies for the Allies, and imposing political and economic sanctions on the Axis states.
==See also== * [[Cairo Conference|First Cairo Conference]] of November 22–26, 1943, attended by President [[Franklin Roosevelt]] of the United States, Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]] of the United Kingdom, and Generalissimo [[Chiang Kai-shek]] of the Republic of China. * [[Adana Conference]] of January 30–31, 1943, attended by President [[İsmet İnönü]] of Turkey and Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]] of the United Kingdom. * [[List of World War II conferences]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/sp1943-44/chapter16.htm U.S. Army: "Strategic Planning for Coalition Warfare, 1943-1944" by Maurice Matloff, Chapter XVI, pp. 379-380.] Center of Military History, United States Army, Washington D.C., 1990. Library of Congress Catalog Card Number 53-61477. First Printed 1959-CMH Pub 1-4. *{{cite book| title = Command Decisions| editor = Kent Roberts Greenfield| url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/70-7_0.htm| publisher = [[United States Army Center of Military History]]| year = 2000 (reissue from 1960)| id = CMH Pub 70-7| chapter = Chapter 10: Overlord Versus the Mediterranean at the Cairo-Tehran Conferences |first = Richard M. | last = Leighton| chapterurl =http://www.history.army.mil/books/70-7_10.htm}} * [http://ww2db.com/battle_spec.php?battle_id=142 World War II Database: Second Cairo Conference (December 4–6, 1943)]

{{About|data interception in electronic systems|other uses|Snarf (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{one source|date=September 2014}} {{confusing|date=May 2011}} }}
'''Snarf''' is a term used by computer programmers meaning to grab a large document, file, content, or data, and use it without the author (owner)'s permission. In the [[UNIX]] community the term means the acquisition of a file or set of files across a network. It also refers to using [[command line]] tools to transfer files through the [[HTTP]], [[Gopher (protocol)|gopher]], [[Finger protocol|finger]], and [[FTP]] protocols without user interaction, and to a method of achieving [[cache coherence]] in a [[multiprocessing]] computer architecture through observation of writes to cached data.
== Example ==
An example of a snarf is the [[Evil twin (wireless networks)|Evil twin attack]], using a simple shell script running software like AirSnarf<ref name="shmoo">{{cite web|url=http://airsnarf.shmoo.com|title='Airsnarf' - A rogue AP setup utility |accessdate=2012-11-03 |author=Potter, Bruce G. |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=1996-10-16 | |website=The Shmoo Group |pages=1 |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=Airsnarf is a simple rogue wireless access point setup utility designed to demonstrate how a rogue AP can steal usernames and passwords from public wireless hotspots. Airsnarf was developed and released to demonstrate an inherent vulnerability of public 802.11b hotspots--snarfing usernames and passwords by confusing users with DNS and HTTP redirects from a competing AP.}}</ref> to create a wireless hotspot complete with a [[captive portal]]. Wireless clients that associate to a snarf access point will receive an IP, DNS, and gateway and appear completely normal. Users will have all of their DNS queries resolve to the attacker's [[IP number]], regardless of their DNS settings, so any website they attempt to visit will bring up a snarf "splash page", requesting a username and password. The username and password entered by unsuspecting users will be mailed to root@localhost. The reason this works is: #Legitimate access points can be impersonated and/or drowned out by rogue access points, and #Users without a means to validate the authenticity of access points will nevertheless give up their hotspot credentials when asked for them
== See also == * [[Bluejacking]] * [[Bluesnarfing]] * [[Pod slurping]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071010094510/http://manageengine.adventnet.com/products/wifi-manager/help/alarms/intrusion-airsnarf-attack.html Airsnarf Attack] *[[wikt:snarf|Wiktionary "snarf"]]

{{about|[[United Kingdom|British]] Story papers|the U.S. version|Dime novel}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2014}}
A '''story paper''' is a periodical [[publication]] similar to a literary magazine, but featuring illustrations and text stories, and aimed towards children and teenagers. Also known in Britain as "boys' weeklies", story papers were phenomenally popular before the outbreak of the [[Second World War]].
Among the most well-known British story paper was ''[[Boy's Own Paper]]'', which ran from 1879 to 1967.
==Beginnings== The first known edition of what would later become known as a "story paper" was ''The Young Gentleman's Magazine'', published in 1777. The first story paper to really take off was ''The Boys' and Girls' Penny Magazine'', first published in September 1832.
In 1866, Charles Stephens began selling ''Boys of England'' on the English streets for a penny—the first "[[penny dreadful]]". Story papers in this style minimized the expense of writing in order to produce an extremely cheap product. Strictly speaking, the "penny dreadful" died off by the turn of the century, but this term was still used to refer to story papers throughout their history. The ''[[Halfpenny Marvel]]'', first published in 1893, was "founded to counteract the pernicious influences of the Penny Dreadfuls", according to its title page. A book about these weeklies (also called "bloods" because of their savage contents) was created in 1948 by [[E. S. Turner]], called ''Boys Will be Boys''.
==Golden Age== [[Image:The Boy's Own Paper, front page, 11 April 1891.jpg|thumb|250px|''The Boy's Own Paper'', front page, 11 April 1891]] Denis Gifford designated the period between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] as the "Golden Age" of story papers. Sales of the story papers were at their highest during these years, as were the fecundity of the authors, the range in genre of magazines, and the colourful variety of the heroes. The most famous story paper hero, [[Sexton Blake]], reached his apex during these years.
World War II caused chaos in Britain, and among other things the story papers had to be shut down as funds were redirected to the war. This is known as the ''Dark Ages'' for story papers, and nearly all of the papers ceased printing in 1939 or 1940.
==Silver Age and modern comics== In the 1950s and 1960s, some story papers such as the ''Rover'' briefly flourished, but television had a growing influence on the attentions of British children. Mergers between publishing houses finished off the remaining story papers, or modified them to become comic books, in the 1970s. Rover was the last survivor and ceased publishing in 1973.<ref name=Kibble-White20>{{cite book |last=Kibble-White |first=Graham |year=2005 |title=The Ultimate Book of British Comics 70 years of mischief, mayhem and cow pies |publisher=Allison & Busby limited |isbn=0749082119 |page=20 }}</ref>
==Format and politics== [[George Orwell]]'s essay, ''[[Boys' Weeklies]]'', outlines the general themes of the story paper in the "Golden Age". As far as Orwell could tell, Britain was the only country in Europe in which story papers were produced. ''[[The Gem]]'' and ''[[The Magnet]]'', the oldest of their kind, featured school serials always centred on a group of characters any reader could identify with. More recent story papers focused on adventure and intrigue, and had a large teenage readership.
According to Orwell, all of the English papers published at the time were stuck in the 1910s and had an underlying conservative slant, which taught children to be deferential to the upper-class. He suggested socialist values could be just as exciting if they followed the story paper format.
There were story papers for children of both sexes, although there was a broad overlap in the actual readership of the two.
==List of story papers==

revision.comment: removed [[Category:1967 in music]]; added [[Category:1967 in American music]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} The '''Tanglewood Symposium''' was a conference that took place from July 23 to August 2, 1967, in [[Lenox, MA|Tanglewood, Massachusetts]]. It was sponsored by the [[MENC: The National Association for Music Education|Music Educators National Conference]] (MENC) in cooperation with the [[Berkshire Music Center]], the [[Theodore Presser Foundation]], and the School of Fine and Applied Arts of [[Boston University]]. The purpose was to discuss and define the role of [[music education]] in contemporary American society and to make recommendations to improve the effectiveness of music instruction. Participants included [[sociologist]]s, scientists, [[labor leader]]s, [[educators]], representatives of corporations, musicians, and people involved with other aspects of music.
==The Symposium== Position papers had been published in the March and April 1967 issues of the ''Music Educators Journal''. The papers served as the bases for discussion at the 1967 MENC divisional conferences and for the Tanglewood Symposium. The sessions were moderated by Max Kaplan, [[Wiley Lee Housewright]] (1913–2003), Allen P. Britton, [[David P. McAllester]], and Karl D. Ernst. Three broad questions were considered: * What are the characteristics and desirable ideologies for an emerging and [[postindustrial society]]? * What are the values and unique functions of music and other arts for individuals and communities in such a society? * How may these potentials be attained?
==The Tanglewood Declaration== The Tanglewood Symposium is summarized in the statement entitled "The Tanglewood Declaration," which provided a philosophical basis for future developments in music education. Of particular importance, the Declaration called for music to be placed in the core of the school curriculum.
*a. Music serves best when its integrity as an art is maintained. *b. Music of all periods, styles, forms, and cultures belongs in the curriculum. The musical repertory should be expanded to involve music of our time in its rich variety, including currently popular teenage music and avant-garde music, American folk music, and the music of other cultures. *c. Schools and colleges should provide adequate time for music programs ranging from pre-school through adult or continuing education. *d. Instruction in the arts should be a general and important part of education in the senior high school. *e. Developments in educational technology, educational television, programmed instruction, and computer-assisted instruction should be applied to music study and research. *f. Greater emphasis should be placed on helping the individual student to fulfill his needs, goals, and potentials. *g. The music education profession must contribute its skills, proficiencies, and insights toward assisting in the solution of urgent social problems as in the "inner city" or other areas with culturally deprived individuals. *h. Programs of teacher education must be expanded and improved to provide music teachers who are specially equipped to teach high school courses in the history and literature of music, courses in the humanities and related arts, as well as teachers equipped to work with the very young, with adults, with the disadvantaged, and with the emotionally disturbed.<ref>Introduction to Music Education, 3rd Edition, Hoffer, Charles R.</ref>
==See also== *[[GO Project]] *[[MENC: The National Association for Music Education|Music Educators National Conference]] *[[The Housewright Symposium / Vision 2020]]

''[[Bulletin of the Council for Research in Music Education]], 63,'' 11–19. * Murphy, J. and Sullivan, G. (1968). ''Music in American Society.'' {{essay-like|date=January 2009}}
The '''Technical Service Council''' was set up to combat the "[[brain drain]]" of Canadian engineers to the [[United States]], when over 20% of the graduating classes were emigrating. [[Ireland]], [[India]], [[New Zealand]] and even [[Switzerland]] have had similar problems.
In 1927, Canadian industry financed the Council, whose directors concluded that a non-profit employment service that was free to graduates might minimize emigration. The service survived the Depression, played a part in recruiting scientists and engineers for war work, pioneered outplacement and expanded to include other professional occupations. It financed major studies of the supply of and demand for engineers and offered free-job-hunting courses to professionals.
Although started in [[Toronto]], the Council eventually had offices in [[Montreal]], [[Winnipeg]], [[Calgary]], [[Edmonton]] and [[Vancouver]] before becoming bankrupt in 1994. It may have reduced the brain drain during its first 20 or 25 years, but it's not possible to judge its later record.
== History ==
=== Beginning ===
In the 1920s over 20% of Canadian engineering graduates emigrated to the United States.<ref>Personal letter from Robert A. Bryce to Neil A. Macdougall, May 19, 1955.</ref><ref name=TSC>Annual Report, Technical Service Council/Le Conseil de Placement Professionnel, Toronto, 1976.</ref> At that time, jobs in the U.S. were both much more numerous and more varied than in Canada. Meanwhile, the number of graduates soared, Canadian employers were unconvinced of the value of engineering degrees and new graduates complained of the lack of jobs.
Robert A. Bryce, president of Macassa Mines Ltd. and Prof. [[H.E.T. Haultain]] of the [[University of Toronto]] resolved to act. In April 1927 they and Rev.Canon H.J. Cody, chairman of the board of governors of the University of Toronto, invited the chief executives of major firms to a dinner at the National Club in Toronto. After hearing how the loss of talent could hamper industry, each of the 12 executives promised $1,000 to fund a non-profit organization to combat the "brain drain". The brain drain, the selling of science to employers and Canadian nationalism were tightly intertwined ideas. The firm was called the Technical Service Council.<ref name=Enros>Enros, Philip C., "The Technical Service Council's Origins: A 'Patriotic Experiment' in Selling Engineers", Journal of Canadian Studies, Vol. 24, No. 4 1989-90 Winter, {{ISSN|0021-9495}}.</ref>
Rolsa Eric Smythe was hired to run the Council. Appropriately, he was a Canadian engineer who had been working in Detroit. (3)
After a study of placement operations in other countries and consultation with employers, the directors decided that engineers would not respond to urges to stay in Canada. Instead the Technical Service Council would find jobs for them by operating a free (to graduates) placement service.<ref name=TSC/> Employers would be invited to donate to the service, although later some companies used the service without contributing.
=== Objectives ===
The objectives were: To retain for Canada young Canadians educated along technical and scientific lines; to bring graduates of universities and technical institutions into practical contact with Canadian industry; to submit to universities the recommendations of industry concerning scientific courses and to aid industry in technical and scientific employment problems.<ref name=TSC1952>Technical Service Council pamphlet, circa 1952.</ref>
=== Early operations ===
A small office was opened in Toronto in 1928 with $30,000 "seed money" from 30 firms to finance a three-year experiment.<ref name=PR1954>Progress Report 1954, Technical Service Council pamphlet.</ref> Between July and December, 159 job hunters registered, 185 jobs were listed by employers and 81 engineers were placed by the staff of two.<ref>name=Enros, Philip C. "The Technical Service Council's Origins: a 'Patriotic Experiment' in Selling Engineers"</ref>
The [[Great Depression]] soon arrived, wiping out many jobs. Some graduates were placed in welcome, but undemanding jobs, like street car conductor. Raising money was difficult and the Council survived only because of grants from the government of [[Ontario]] in 1932-34 and sometimes, Smythe's forgoing his salary. It was decided to ask those who had found jobs through the TSC to make donations. This produced some money, but the organization had a hand-to-mouth existence until 1957, apart from the [[World War II]] years. (3)
By June 30, 1933, over 1,180 personnel had been placed, 110 of whom were repatriated Canadians. Expenses for the first five years of operations were $44,988.<ref>"The Technical Service Council - a Report Covering the First Five-Year Period, June 30th, 1928 to June 30th, 1933."</ref> In 1933, 111 men and women were placed by the Council's staff of two.<ref name=TSC/>
Even then it was clear that engineers needed business knowledge. The Council persuaded the [[University of Western Ontario]] to offer a diploma course in management for engineers.<ref name=TSC/> Then such a course was novel, if not unique. In 1951 numerous employers and graduates in [[ceramic engineering]] were surveyed on behalf of the [[University of Saskatchewan]] to estimate future demand. Some time later a similar survey was made for the University of Toronto. As a result of these studies, both universities discontinued their ceramic engineering programs.<ref>"Ceramic Engineers". ''Clay Products News'', Jan. 1952.</ref>
By 1938, in response employers' demand for "one-stop service", the Council expanded to include executives, accountants, marketing, production and personnel staff.<ref name=TSC/> A year later, the economy had improved, but the Council's placements were mainly in [[Ontario]] and [[Quebec]], where Canada's industry was concentrated.
=== Wartime years ===
Job vacancies soared with the start of World War II. Shipyards, steel mills, armaments and munitions factories, aircraft manufacturers and construction companies urgently needed engineers. Few engineers even considered emigrating to the United States because of patriotic reasons and the plethora of jobs.
The Technical Service Council was the only placement service allowed to operate during the war.<ref name=TSC/> Its bank of professionals was such an important national resource that 15 recruiters from Defence Industries Ltd., the major munitions manufacturer, were loaned to the Council.<ref name=TSC/>
===Post-war activities ===
After the war, veterans were entitled to free university tuition. Therefore, record numbers of engineers were graduated in 1949 and 1950.<ref>"Employment Outlook Promising", ''5TO Engineers' Newsletter'', prepared by the Technical Service Council, Nov. 10, 1950.</ref><ref>"Engineering Employment at Record Level", Technical Service Council news release N12/50, Nov. 17, 1950.</ref> Graduates of Western and Maritime universities, both in areas with limited industry, greatly outnumbered local vacancies. Many engineers moved to Ontario, Quebec and the United States. About 2,500 professional men emigrated to the United States in 1950 alone.<ref name=pastures>"Are Those Pastures Greener?" Unsigned editorial in ''The Globe & Mail'', Toronto, May 6, 1952. Reprinted by the Technical Service Council.</ref> Nevertheless, one study showed that the exodus of technically trained graduates dropped from 27% of the graduating classes in 1927 to under 10% in 1951.<ref name=someone>"Someone Has Done Something about Canada's Loss of Skills," unsigned editorial, ''The Telegram'', Toronto, Oct. 5, 1951. Reprinted by the Technical Service Council.</ref>
Pioneering work was done on group interviews and recruitment advertising in 1950-52.<ref name=Macdougall>Macdougall, Neil A. "Make Your Personnel Advertising Dollars Count", ''Personnel'', May, 1952.</ref><ref>"The Group Oral in Canada", ''Canadian Personnel & Industrial Relations Journal'', April, 1956.</ref> The latter study showed how employers could increase response to their ads. The Federal government engaged the Council to write a handbook on the job market for immigrants while the Ontario Government asked the Council to appraise opportunities for prospective immigrants from [[Great Britain]].
Canadian industry contributed more than $300,000 to the Council between 1927 and 1953.<ref name="PR1954" /> During the same period, employers listed 16,533 job vacancies.<ref name=TSC1952/> 6,817 men with special training were placed in key positions in business and industry.<ref name="PR1954"/> The Council registered and interviewed 24,607 men with higher education.<ref name="PR1954"/> The qualifications of each were carefully cross-indexed and maintained for employers.<ref name="PR1954"/> An additional 100,000 individuals were interviewed to assess qualifications and give free vocational advice. The average cost per placement rose from $50 to $100 between 1948 and 1954.<ref name="PR1954"/>
Between 1951 and 1956, 3,072 engineers, equivalent to 31% of graduating classes in engineering, emigrated to the United States.<ref name=Ex-Canadian>"Ex-Canadian Engineers Could Staff World's Largest Missile Centre", Technical Service Council news release N1/57, Nov. 14, 1957.</ref> They could have staffed the largest missile centre in the Western World.<ref name=Ex-Canadian/> In 1951 the equivalent of 11% of the graduating classes in engineering left for the United States. In 1956, as immigrants were less likely to be drafted, the percentage had soared to 46%.<ref name=Ex-Canadian/>
In 1957 the Council almost collapsed, but it was revived by new management who increased placement fees.
Shortages of engineers and scientists in Canada often coincided with equally acute shortages in the United States. American companies then recruited actively in Canada, as they did following the 1959 cancellation of Canada's much-vaunted [[Avro Arrow]] jet fighter. In addition, Canadians completing post-graduate training in the U.S. often found getting a job locally easier than searching for one in distant Canada.<ref name=reversing>''Reversing the Brain Drain'', a report for the Ministry of State, Science and Technology, Technical Service Council, 1987.</ref>
In 1962 a branch in [[Montreal]] called Technical Service Council/Le Conseil de Placement Professionnel was opened. It was followed by others in [[Winnipeg]], [[Calgary]], [[Edmonton]] and [[Vancouver]].<ref name=TSC/>
=== Outplacement and other activities ===
The Council was one of the pioneers of [[outplacement]] (then called relocation counselling) in Canada.<ref name=TSC/><ref name=Macdougall/><ref>Feature article on relocation counselling work by Technical Service Council and another consultant. Title and author unknown. ''Harvard Business Review''. Circa 1970.</ref> Its first contract in 1970 eventually developed into a significant activity. In addition to individual counselling, free office services and other benefits, clients were given ''How to Job Hunt Effectively,'' a substantial hand and work book.<ref name=Harvey>Harvey, Edward B. and Murthy, K.S.R., ''Engineering Supply & Demand, 1988-1998'', Technical Service Council, Toronto, 1988. {{ISBN|0-920924-32-8}}.</ref> The book was also available to the public and over 5,000 copies were sold.
From 1967 regular one-day employment interviewing courses for line managers were run in major cities. Students received written critiques of their interviews with actors.
By 1971 out-of-work university graduates were so numerous that free "How to Job Hunt" courses were held in several cities.<ref name=TSC/> As another public service, over $200,000. was spent researching and publishing ten-year forecasts of the supply of and demand for engineering graduates in 1975 and again in 1988. Both studies were intended to improve understanding of the job market, candidate mobility and help minimize "mismatch".<ref name=Harvey/> They were provided free to Canadian universities and sold at below cost to employers.<ref name=TSC/>
In the same year, an executive search division, Bryce, Haultain & Associates, was opened and named after two of the Council's co-founders.<ref name=TSC/>
===Later placement activities===
By 1976 the Council had placed over 16,000 men and women.<ref name=TSC/> An equal number were estimated to have rejected job offers from the Council's client companies. Studies showed that 25% of job listings were never filled from any source. Employers' reasons included budget cuts, inability to find someone who filled the job specifications, candidates' high asking salaries, reorganizations and a belated realization that existing staff could do the job.
In 1976 573 firms were members.<ref name=TSC/> Annual membership fees were mainly $100 to $500., depending upon company size and usage. Placement fees were kept low in order to attract job listings. The greater the choice of vacancies, the more likely candidates were to stay in Canada. Placement fees for member companies were 4% to 5% of the placement's annual income.<ref name=TSC/> Commercial [[employment agencies]] charged 20% to 30%.<ref name=TSC/>
Over 17,000 engineers and scientists emigrated from Canada to the United States between 1960 and 1979. The number of engineers emigrating declined from 1,209 in 1967 to only 289 in 1977, and the number of chemists emigrating dropped from 156 to 58 during the same period.<ref>" 'Brain Drain' Surge Feared", ''Toronto Star'', July 17, 1979.</ref> However, engineers and scientists emigrating increased from 727 in 1982 to 1,433 in 1985.<ref name=reversing/>
Active job listings reached 4,328 in June 1981,an astonishing figure for such a clearing house.<ref name=jobs>{{Citation | last = Technical Service Council | title = | newspaper = Ontario Technologist | pages = | date = Summer 1981 }}</ref> Orders plummeted when Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]]'s highly controversial [[National Energy Program]] took effect. About half the Council's staff was laid off.
Nevertheless, between 1928 and 1988, over 46,000 men and women had received job offers from about 1,700 of the Council's employer clients.<ref name=Harvey/>
Frequent dramatic swings in the job market caused the Council to build a financial reserve equal to two times' annual operating expenses.<ref name=TSC/> The reserve was over three times' expenses in December, 1991, but the Council was declared bankrupt in September, 1994.<ref>Technical Service Council Financial Statements, Dec. 31, 1992, Doane Raymond, auditors.</ref>
== Evaluation of results ==
From 1928 to 1939, job vacancies were mainly advertised locally so job hunters had difficulty learning of distant jobs. The Maritimes and West had so little industry that their substantial engineering graduating classes had to seek positions elsewhere. Employers seldom sought professionals through the Federal employment service while universities had tiny or non-existent placement services. This lack of job information made the Council's numerous industrial contacts especially important to job hunters. The exodus of technically trained Canadians is said to have dropped from 27% of graduating classes in 1927 to under 10% in 1951 <ref name=someone/> and 5% in 1967.<ref>"The Story of TSC - a Unique Placement Service", ''The Professional Engineer and Engineering Digest'', May, 1967.</ref>
Any evaluation of the later years is difficult. The number of job vacancies and job hunters both increased. But often supply and demand were out of sync, encouraging emigration. Universities devoted more resources to placing their graduates, but often gave little attention to experienced graduates. Commercial employment agencies expanded, but few lasted five years because of the erratic job market. Eventually, one and then another national newspaper spread news of distant vacancies. Although graduates had better information than ever, the Council was still busy. Despite this, 2,500 professional men moved to the United States in 1950 alone.<ref name=pastures/> It is impossible to judge the Council's impact on the "brain drain" since then.
The Ministry of State, Science and Technology asked the Council to study the feasibility of a National Register of Canadians in research-oriented occupations who are working or studying out of the country.<ref name=reversing/> The study found that 65% of employers contacted had a strong or moderate interest in a register. It was estimated that only one or two per cent of candidates would find jobs through the register. Neither the register nor a free handbook on job hunting in Canada would get at the reasons why many Canadians do not return: a perceived lack of opportunities in their specialty and lack of research support in Canada.<ref name=reversing/>
The study noted that efforts by the Association of Medical Colleges of Canada and the [[Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada]] to recruit Canadians in the U.S. had failed. In 1986 twenty British firms advertised for British-trained engineers in [[North America]]. The ads produced 6,500 replies and about 1,800 job offers. Only 89 offers were accepted at what was considered an uneconomical cost.<ref name=reversing/>

16. Cuddihy, Basil Robert. "How to Give Phased-out Managers a New Chance", ''Harvard Business Review'', Vol.54, No.4. Jul.-Aug. 1974. Neither the Technical Service Council nor the other consultant used is named. (This entry replaces No.16 above.)
22. Technical Service Council advertisement in ''Ontario Technologist'' and about six other Canadian technical publications. Summer, 1981.

web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/what-s-on/tv-radio/tv-drama-to-focus-on-malcolm-webster-murders-1-3262761 |title=TV drama to focus on Malcolm Webster murders |publisher=The Scotsman |date=2014-01-10 http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep1week12/widower#.UzxnyPldVO1 |title = The Widower |publisher = ITV Press Centre |date = 3 March 2014 |website = itv.com |accessdate= 2 April 2014 }} Webster's
